SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Last year, the Government responded to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform relating to the operation during the 1984 general election of the 1983-84 amendments to Commonwealth electoral legislation and indicated that, due to the exigencies of the legislative program, legislation to give effect to the acceptable recommendations in the report will be introduced in stages.

Honourable senators will recall that the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Act 1987 gave effect to those recommendations which were at the time considered essential for the effective conduct of the next general election. That Act created inconsistencies between the Commonwealth Electoral Act and Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. The amendments contained in this Bill will remove those inconsistencies and are therefore considered essential for the conduct of any future referendum.
Mr President, the Bill will bring the referendum Act into line with the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the following respects:
It will ensure that overseas polling officials are subject to the same penalties for neglect of duty as officials in Australia;
It will extend from 10 to 13 days the period for the return of all postal votes sent by electors directly to divisional returning officers;
It will bind the Crown in right of the Commonwealth or the States;
It will repeal the requirement that enrolled voters at some time during the three months prior to the poll live within the division in order to vote;
It will remove existing time limits on the ability to alter polling day and/or return of the writs
It will enable the Electoral Commission to extend by 48 hours the time in which acts must be completed in the event of a failure by any person to perform a statutory duty or function; and
It will repeal the requirement that printers furnish returns of referendum printing.

Mr President, the Bill also gives effect to the Joint Select Committee's three recommendations which are specific to referendums. Those relate to the presentation of the Yes and No cases, the formality of votes and obligation on broadcasters and publishers to furnish referendum returns.

The Bill makes provision for the preparation and distribution of arguments for and against referendum proposals in a form suitable for the visually impaired. Presently the act specifies that the only money that the Commonwealth may spend on the Yes and No cases is for the preparation, printing and distribution of the pamphlet. This has been taken to preclude the preparation of the Yes and No cases in spoken form suitable for the visually impaired.
The Bill provides that only an unequivocal Yes or No answer should be regarded as formal.

The Bill removes the obligation on broadcasters and publishers to furnish returns for a referendum where it is held in conjunction with an election. Where elections and referendums are held at the same time, no meaningful information is available relating to expenditure on the referendum since it is impossible to distinguish between election and referendum expenditure in the returns furnished by broadcasters and publishers.

The proposed amendments to the referendum act are based on recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and conform in substance to provisions already included in the Electoral Act.
I wish the new chairman and Committee every success in their future endeavours. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 March, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday evening I was considering the provisions of the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill needs to be looked at in the right context, because on the face of it it sets out a whole range of measures which have a very real sense of urgency about them. It is a fairly short Bill and it starts off with a new definition of `identified property'. It then proceeds to spell out what are described as `unlawful acts', and then establishes a regime of inspectors with power of entry and search. It also provides for the nomination and consent of certain judges who are capable of granting warrants to facilitate the entry and search of inspectors and finally it provides for a penalty of $1,000, or imprisonment for 12 months, or both, for persons who without reasonable excuse obstruct or hinder an inspector in the exercise of his duties.

SPEECH.PARA: What justifies the Government to introduce legislation which would bring about a whole new approach to the idea of conservation preservation? I think we have to recognise that Australia has reached a situation, in large measure I think due to the efforts of Senator Puplick, the shadow spokesman for the environment, in which all of the States acknowledge that there is a role to be played by the Federal Government in the preservation of the environment. That is a very healthy situation and it is one that I think is widely acknowledged in the community as being desirable. It does not for one moment encroach on the proper rights of the States and their ultimate powers to determine land usage. But what it does do is undermine the very basis for a Bill of this nature, because we can only assume objectively that the imperative for it was that there was somehow an urgent need to preserve areas that might otherwise be torn away from us, that might be ripped up and flogged and that might be desecrated before there is a chance to preserve them. There is not a skerrick of evidence to suggest that there is any such urgency around Australia in any of those areas. What we have is a cynical attempt by the Government, and the new Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, in particular, to fabricate confrontation, to raise political opportunism to an art form and somehow to try to curry favour with the conservation movement by embarking upon a whole series of actions designed to raise the ante. That is what is obnoxious about this legislation. No-one for one moment quarrels with the proposition that there should be enforceable legislation that would enable the proper listing of those properties deemed to have outstanding natural and cultural significance.

We on this side of the chamber are wholeheartedly in support of efforts that would involve the listing of those properties that would genuinely qualify. But this Government is not about that. It is in unseemly haste to get political marks on the board and to attempt to railroad issues, and even courts, in such a way that the debate is changed, so that it is able to claim credit for streamlining the process in its eyes but in reality it is simply dragooning others into a situation where vastly more land is proclaimed, or intended to be proclaimed, for World Heritage listing than there ought to be in the proper method of going about the listing process.

If we examine the provisions of the Bill we find that the Government claims-and this is what emerges from Senator Richardson's second reading speech, which on the face of it is fairly innocuous; it is probably more significant from what it does not say rather than what it does-that there is a need to redefine `identified property' in order to follow the provisions of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage more closely. The fact is that the convention creates no duty to protect individual world hertiage properties and makes no mention of interim protective measures. Yet that is what this Bill is all about. If we look at the way in which identified property is defined, it becomes clear that this definition is no more than an elaborate charade because a reference in the legislation to `identified property' is a reference to:
any property in respect of which one or more of the following conditions is satisfied . . .

Certainly, the first three conditions are quite reasonable and plausible. The first is that the property is subject to an inquiry, the second is that the property is subject to World Heritage List nomination and the third is that the property is included in the World Heritage List. There might be some argument about what is meant by the words `subject to' and it may well be that this is premature in the sense that if one simply foreshadowed a listing it would be caught by these provisions. Nonetheless, in general terms, one would have to say that if an inquiry had been established, if World Heritage listing was imminent or if the property was in fact on the List then that would be sufficient to identify the property. However, it is the last condition that really gives the Government carte blanche. That provision says:
the property forms part of the cultural heritage or natural heritage . . .

There is nothing in the provisions of that subsection of the Bill to say in whose eyes or whose terms it should form part of the cultural heritage. No doubt there would just be a mere assertion that that was so. That condition continues:
. . . and is declared by the regulations to form part of the cultural heritage . . .

That is a very unhealthy approach because it means that the Government can simply declare that a property forms part of the cultural or natural heritage and that would then be taken as given. In other words, there would not be an objective assessment; there would be pressure brought to bear on the courts to accept the prescription of the regulation without going behind it. It is an attempt to state a conclusive position and, to the extent that that would pre-empt the ability of the States and other interested parties to dispute the legitimacy of the regulations and the propriety of declaring an area to be part of the cultural and natural heritage, it is a denial of natural justice. That is a phase that is often thrown around loosely, but what it means and what it is held to mean in law is that those persons with an interest in a matter should have the opportunity to be heard before a decision is taken against them; they should also be entitled to be heard by a tribunal that is free of bias. In this situation it would be absolutely impossible for that to occur because the Government would have pre-empted the debate, would have declared an area by regulation and would effectively have done what it could to ensure that the court did not go behind that determination. I believe that that is one of the most insidious aspects of this legislation.

What concerns me even more is that the powers of entry and search are given to inspectors who are created by the legislation. Inspectors are given very wide powers of entry and search, power to take photographs and record occurrences, to inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing. If we look for a definition of `an eligible thing' we find that it is anything that is prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this definition. If that is not carte blanche I do not know what is. It is quite clear that inspectors have almost unlimited powers. What are they able to do and where are they able to go? Inspectors shall not enter an eligible place unless the consent of the owner has been obtained. One would have thought that that was reasonable, but that is only one means by which they may enter. They do not have to get permission at all because either they obtain the consent or they get a warrant or the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the inspector believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to enter in order to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of anything; and
(ii) the entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant. . .

That is in the eye of the beholder. If an inspector believes that somehow he is reasonably justified in trampling on to the property, taking photographs, examining, inspecting and confiscating then he is at liberty to do so. We are given no explanation at all as to why and in what circumstances such conduct could be justified. After all, if we are talking about areas of outstanding natural and cultural significance, we are talking about very large areas of land. They are not areas that are about to disappear off the face of the earth; they are not areas that are somehow transient in quality. They are supposed to be of enduring grandeur, of timeless quality. It is very difficult to see why there is a need for such a provision, unless it is to provoke a political confrontation. Where there is a sensitive area, the Government sends in the troops, stirs up a bit of trouble, raises the ante and then claims the political credit for supposedly being on the right side. That is what is insidious about this sort of provision.

Worst of all, the power to grant a warrant is vested in a judge. But it is not just any judge. It is common practice for legislation to require a warrant to be granted by a judge. Certainly interception warrants, for example, can be granted by Federal Court judges. They can be granted not just by selected judges, but by any judge. One goes to the court, and if it is out of session to the judge in the practice court, on an impartial basis and one takes one's chances in a sense. One relies on the integrity of the Bench, and asks a judge to grant a warrant. That is precisely what this legislation does not do, and what is so offensive about it. It enables the Minister to approach a judge to ask that judge to consent to be an eligible judge and, having obtained the consent, the Minister then nominates the judge and declares him in writing to be a judge to whom consents are in force.

That is thoroughly offensive. That is a frontal attack on the independence of the judiciary. One of the tenets of our Constitution is that there should be a separation of powers, that there should be no incestuous interlocking of the judiciary and the Executive, and yet we find here that not only has the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories not learnt the lesson of Mr Justice Murphy-where there was a very close overlap and one could say one well beyond the bounds of propriety in terms of the mixture between politicians and judges-but also, if we look at the transcripts of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and what is emerging from the diaries of Sir Terence Lewis, we see a very unhealthy interrelationship between judges and politicians. That is the very sort of thing that has led the Victorian Supreme Court to say it will play no part in royal commissions, it will not preside over political events no matter how worthy or honourable they might be. That is because the judiciary is rightly concerned that it can and might be contaminated by being brought into the political arena.

I want to mention the name of one Federal Court judge who could well be put in a very invidious position. I make no adverse reflection upon him at all; my understanding is that he is a first class judge of that court, and he is certainly eminently well qualified for his position. Mr Justice Wilcox, now a judge of the Federal Court, was the President of the Australian Conservation Foundation. One could imagine that if Mr Justice Wilcox were to consent to be nominated he could well find himself quite unfairly exposed to criticism if he were to grant a warrant. If he were not to grant it, it may be said, as often happens in the law, that he was bending over backwards to be seen to be impartial. Again that would put him in an invidious position. If he therefore chose the safe course of not offering his consent, he would be opting out to that extent and the system would be deprived of the services of a first rate judicial officer.

It is thoroughly indefensible to put a judge in such a position. A person of integrity should be able to approach a matter without having to worry about the political considerations, and yet as a result of this contaminated legislation we will have a situation in which judges will be picked off selectively, where friends of the Minister can be approached, where judges who might be thought to be more sympathetic to the cause are asked to give their consent and where judges are perhaps put in a position where they feel they have to give consent. In all sorts of ways a very unhealthy relationship could develop.

As Senator Puplick has previously pointed out in this debate, it is not just any judge; it is judges of the Parliament. It is not just Federal Court judges; it is not Supreme Court judges. Let us bear in mind that the New South Wales Supreme Court has a land and environment court, so on the face of it it would have people qualified in and who may well have a particular interest and knowledge of some of the technical areas and legal aspects that might arise with the granting of a warrant in this area. But, no, it relates to any judge of a court of the Parliament-presumably a Family Court judge or a Federal Court judge specialising in bankruptcy or industrial relations. It is a nonsense. There should be access to any judge of a Supreme Court of a State, the Federal Court, or perhaps the High Court, on a thoroughly impartial basis.

Senator Evans seems to be chortling away, completely oblivious to and obviously uninterested in the judicial processes. Now that he has been thrown out of his formerly high office of Attorney-General he is demonstrating his contempt for what would previously have had him jumping to his feet in horror, being a former civil libertarian and concerned with the due processes of the law. He now shows a complete and utter lack of interest in it. It is perhaps symptomatic of the cynical approach of the Government.

That is one of the worst aspects of this legislation. There is no need for inspectors. There is no sense of urgency. Indeed, one has to be very quizzical about the whole concept of interim and interlocutory applications in the light of the recent High Court judgment. If one shares the misgivings of judges such as Mr Justice Dawson, the external affairs power has now been taken to a point where there is virtually no limit on it. A very respected commentator, Mr David Solomon, expresses grave fears for States' rights in this area and for land usage questions and says that there is effectively no limitation on the power of the courts. As Mr Justice Dawson says, if all one needs to do is relate it to a treaty, and if that needs only to be based on international concern, it is not hard to envisage that almost any matter will be subject to the external affairs power.

I do not take a narrow view of these matters. There are legitimate ways in which the external affairs power can be used. But it has to be used with great care. When commentators such as David Solomon say, as he recently said in the Australian newspaper, `What the States should be jumping up and down about is the further growth of the Commonwealth's legislative powers through its constitutional power to make laws about ``external affairs'',' it is clear that the time has come not only to question the external affairs power but also to look at why there is a necessity for legislation such as the Bill before us.

I would like to conclude by referring to what is perhaps one of the most offensive pieces of chicanery on the part of a politician that I have come across in recent years. I refer to the nomination form from the Government of Australia for inclusion of the wet tropical rainforests of north-east Australia on the World Heritage List. This is a formal document presented by the Australian Government and signed on its behalf by Senator Richardson in December last year. One would have thought it was put forward in good faith as a basis for the nomination committee of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) in due course to make a judgment about the merits of the north-east wet tropical rainforests. As is often the case with matters that are put before courts and other tribunals, those courts rely very much on the integrity, honesty and accuracy of the document. But what do we have in this document? Under the heading `Responsible administration' it states:
The Government of Australia has enacted the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 to implement its responsibilities and obligations arising from the World Heritage Conventions.
That is unexceptionable. It continues:
A joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Governments is envisaged to assume responsibility for administration of the property.

That is absolutely untrue. As Senator Parer has pointed out already, when this was signed in December of last year there was absolutely no prospect that the Queensland Government would be on side. The Premier at the time, as we all know, was Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen-not the sort of individual likely to have caved in, not the sort of person likely to have taken the much more reasonable and rational approach now being adopted by Mr Ahern, but someone who quite clearly would not have paid any attention to the blandishments of the likes of Senator Richardson. What was the basis for asserting that it was envisaged that the Queensland Government would assume joint responsibility with the Australian Government? There was no basis whatsoever. The document, under the heading `Agent Responsible for preservation/conservation', states:
The envisaged joint authority of the Australian and Queensland Governments will also have responsibilities regarding the preservation and conservation of the World Heritage Area.

Again, that is a deliberate misstatement of fact. We know that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is under the joint administration of the Australian and Queensland governments, after a tortuous period of negotiations, after a lot of toing-and-froing. It is not the sort of agreement that is entered into quickly. Quite clearly, time is of the essence in terms of negotiation. This document simply asserts what might be wishful thinking on the part of the Australian Government, but which had no reasonable foundation in fact. It is a disgraceful position. It amounts to Senator Richardson having misled the international community by asserting that the Queensland Government would be party to a joint venture of administration when there was no reasonable prospect of that occurring. That is a very cogent example of how this Government is desperately trying to make political capital out of highly political stances, with no thought at all for the proper negotiating processes or for proper and calm consideration of whether matters should be properly listed on the World Heritage List; rather, it is a desperate attempt to up the ante, to push through legislation in such a way that parties are put on the defensive.

This nomination form is nothing less than a callous exercise in propaganda. An apology should be made not only to UNESCO but to the international community at large. It means that the word of the Australian Government will have to be much more closely scrutinised in the future. It means that political imperatives have overtaken the ordinary standards of propriety and morality that should accompany the presentation of such a document. Senator Richardson deserves to be chastised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There should be a full and proper explanation as to why a Minister of the Crown was able to make such an assertion when there was no reasonable foundation in fact. One could say that not only was there no reasonable foundation, but no foundation and no prospect at that time, that the Queensland Government would have a bar of any such joint venture. That characterises the approach of the Government to this piece of legislation.

The legislation is totally unnecessary. It does nothing to advance the cause of preservation of the environment and does nothing to assist the proper consideration of properties for world heri-tage listing. It is unnecessary and it ought to be withdrawn. All of the powers that have been recently held by the High Court of Australia to be available will be available in the future. If there is any urgent need, injunctions can be granted to restrain abuse. There is no need for this whole regime of inspectors that will corrupt the independence of the judiciary and lead to a very unholy interaction of judges and politicians. It is a thoroughly distasteful and unnecessary piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Conservation Le-gislation Amendment Bill 1988. As far as I can see, it is basically about shifting the responsibility for jurisdiction that should be Australia's to an overseas body. I say an overseas body because, of the 21 members of the World Heritage Committee of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation that deals with these matters, only seven members-and I stress, only seven-can be regarded as having many common interests with Australia. In other words, seven are truly Australian allies. I also note that Australia's membership will expire in 1989. I am not sure whether Australia will be a member of that Committee after that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that Australia should give away the final determination process regarding its main asset. The main assets of any country are its agricultural, pastoral and mining areas. I know that we need good conservation policies. No honourable senator knows better than I that we have to conserve the land; otherwise we cannot carry on a lifelong business in agriculture and have a good asset to pass down to future generations. Australia has already locked up 20 per cent of its land which used to have multiple uses. If further regulations are imposed and if we do what the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) asks, that figure could easily rise to 40 per cent.

The main brunt of the provisions of the Bill will be borne by country people, those 11 per cent-I stress that-of Australians who earn 84 per cent of Australia's foreign export income. Western Australia is tired of carrying the burden of eastern State society. Although the Federal Government has not yet declared any areas in Western Australia, certain conservation groups have requests before various bodies to have vast areas declared, including Shark Bay, the Kimberleys, wildflower regions, the D'Entrecasteaux National Park and surrounds, and the Nullarbor Plain.

The area in question at Shark Bay has been held by one family for 113 years. In other words, that family is in its fourth generation there and it has two stations. The Western Australian Government has declared the area to be a sensitive area. The family has been dealing with the Western Australian Government for a number of years in order to protect this sensitive area and they have come to certain arrangements., However, they have been overridden by the ACF, which ran to the Federal Government and is trying to have the area listed under the World Heritage provisions. The arrangements which the station owners made with the State Government have been overridden.

When the ACF took an interest in that area it was lazy-that is the word for it-in defining the area it wanted. Apparently the easiest way to become an expert on an area is to drive down the main road and look from side to side. That is exactly what the ACF did in this case. Taking a third of the station on the sea side, the ACF drew the lines on its map taking in the bitumen road. It is quite likely that the piece of land on that side will be taken from the station. It just happens that the homestead, the shearing shed and the bores that supply the homestead built by the family are on that side. All development, such as buildings and improvements, are on that side. Just in case honourable senators are not aware of the areas around Australia that the ACF is trying to put on the World Heritage List, I have a list which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
Great Barrier Reef
Great Sandy Region
South West Tasmania
Lord Howe Island
Arnhem Land expanding on West Arnhem
Cape York Peninsula
Prince Regent River
Ayers Rock and Arid Zone Region
The Channel Country-Lake Eyre (encompassing Simpson Desert)
Shark Bay
The Western Australian Wild Flower Region
The Central Highlands-Tasmania
Antarctica
Macquarie Island

TALK.START.PARA: —The points I have raised about Shark Bay are of particular concern. I turn now to the effects that listing would have on the areas nominated by the ACF. Listing would cause the cattle industry to move from the north-west of Western Australia. Alongside Queensland, that is probably one of Australia's largest cattle-raising areas. It was opened up in about 1860 when the Durack family-no doubt Senator Durack is a descendant of that family-drove cattle from north Queensland across the Northern Territory. After two years hardship, it settled in the Kimberleys. With the Kimberleys on the list, we could see the end of the cattle industry in that area and a reduction in mining. Of course, mining includes the production of oil, which is a very important commodity for the welfare of Australia. Many pastoral and farming areas would be lost as a result of the expanding wildflower areas. I do not know about the rest of Australia, but in Western Australia wildflower areas are not very well defined. One turns up here today, another turns up somewhere else next year, and so on. It is a very wide-ranging net. I have no great beef about the D'Entrecasteaux National Park.

SPEECH.PARA: The Nullarbor Plain is a strange area. What a farce it would be to move into the Nullarbor Plain. There are minimal stock there. I can remember coming over on the east-west train in about 1960. They were fencing the areas then and sheep were moving in. It is very well run. There is a lot of underground water there, so water is not a problem. What a farce it would be to get the stock out of there. If the Nullarbor Plain were taken out, it may be a good way of removing the Labor Federal member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, who used to be a pastoralist in the region before entering Federal Parliament. If the sheep were removed from the plain it would go back to being used by rabbits alone.

Clause 4 of the Bill repeals subsection 3 (2) of the Act, which contained the former definition of `identified property'. Both the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech of the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook) claim that the repeal and redefinition of identified property follows more closely the procedures which the World Heritage Convention requires Australia to follow in protecting properties of cultural or natural heritage as defined in the Convention. It is hard to reconcile this claim with the provisions of the Convention, which creates no duty to protect individual World Heritage List properties and makes no mention of interim measures or inquiries to consider whether a property forms part of the cultural heritage or national heritage.

Clause 5 introduces a new section 3a which redefines `identified property' in a way that would allow the Federal Government to widen its scope and broaden its involvement in the management agenda of each State. Repealed subsection 3 (2) contained the original definition of `identified property'. Its repeal has swept away the threshold that the property form part of the cultural heritage or the natural heritage as defined in the Convention. It was the Federal Government's compliance with this requirement that could be tested in the High Court of Australia. In the new section there is no threshold requirement where section 3a applies in respect of properties subject to inquiry, properties subject to World Heritage nomination or properties included in the World Heritage List.

Let us turn to the system of inspectors. The Bill states that inspectors may act only with the consent of the property owner, on the basis of a judicial warrant or in serious or urgent circumstances. Proposed new section 17a deals with the appointment of inspectors for the purposes of the Act. Here the Bill deals with what an inspector can do. Read in conjunction with the definitions of `eligible purpose' and `eligible place', it means that the inspectors have formidable powers to go anywhere, except into dwelling houses. Proposed new section 17 is couched in the broadest terms and allows an inspector to enter property without warrant when he believes that entry is necessary to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of an `eligible thing'. An eligible thing is anything that the Federal Government or the Minister believe or declare to be an eligible thing. It is a very wide definition. There is an attempt to avoid abuse of the powers of inspection by providing that inspectors cannot go into private houses. In cases were inspectors cannot find the owner and do not know where he is, they are given carte blanche to do what they want to do. I have seen such systems working before.

I read in the West Australian yesterday a statement made by our friend Senator Sanders from Tasmania. He said that there would be no worry about finding the owner of the land involved because most of the land was crown land. That is probably one of the most hypocritical statements I have heard in this chamber-and I have heard quite a few in my short time here. Senator Sanders knows full well, as do other senators and I, that most crown land is subject to pastoral leases, oil or mineral exploration leases or other sorts of licences. These are licences that people pay money for and licences that may have been held for a long time.

There is no definition of a person in charge of an `eligible thing'. As I said, there is no onus on an inspector to contact the owner of the land. We only have an inspector's word that he has tried to find the owner. I can imagine the sort of effort an inspector would make to find who owned land in remote areas such as Shark Bay, the Kimberleys or the Nullarbor.

In proposed new section 17 there is a secrecy provision. It is a very curious provision. I do not know why it is to be included in the legislation. Its purpose is not clear. Supposedly, it is to keep confidential what the inspector finds out. It is more likely that it is to prevent owners finding out. In the mining industry an individual or company pegging a claim must not only put a number and the name of the claimant on the datum peg but also lodge that information, with the prescribed fees, at the mining office and, by registered mail, notify the owner that that land will be the subject of a claim. We had quite a debate in this House last night on that matter when considering the heritage listing Bill introduced by Senator Walters, a senator from Tasmania. Of course that Bill was not successful and I heard all the excuses on earth as to why one could not find the owner of a property.

I would like to comment now on compensation. The Commonwealth is liable for a certain amount of compensation, which in the Bill is described as a `reasonable amount'. That reasonable amount is subject to an agreement by the two parties. I know which party would have the upper hand in those negotiations between the Commonwealth and individuals concerned. I think that the Commonwealth has a deeper pocket.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you read the legislation?

—I have read it. The Bill and its memorandum describe the amount as `reasonable compensation'. However, the point is that an individual is very frightened about going to litigation. That was borne out in relation to another matter debated in this House earlier in the week. Should the two parties not agree then the Federal Court of Australia is to have jurisdiction at the suit of the claimant. I want to know what the Government means by `reasonable compensation'. No-one has really told me. I can assure the Senate that a land-holder who has spent a lifetime in one area, as I have, would require more than `reasonable compensation' to get him to move. It is all very well to say that reasonable compensation will be offered to a land-holder. But there have been families at Shark Bay, for example, for generations. The Commonwealth would be able to say to these people, `This is reasonable compensation. Now you go somewhere else'. I am sure that those people would want to stay in the pastoral industry. They would have to move further from the Gascoyne into the Kimberleys. The Commonwealth would be able to tell them that they have to look for another property. Most probably that property will not be on the market. If a person has to be moved, he has got to be given more than reasonable compensation; in other words, more than the market value. As a property developer I have had experience of the situation of trying to move the fellow next door. If the Government wants to move miners, farmers and forestry operators, it must pay these people more than reasonable compensation. It must pay them enough to enable them to establish themselves somewhere else--
—It would be unconstitutional. Read section 51 of the Constitution.

—Yes, and giving people meaningful employment does not mean picking papers up after tourists. In this chamber the other day I heard Senator Richardson say that tourism in Australia now is worth more than the Australian wool clip. I would like to take him to task on that matter. I disagree with that. However, let me assure the Minister that when the Australian dollar turns around the Australian sheep flock will still be there to shear, but tourists can be fleeced only once.

SPEECH.PARA: This is another Bill to take away the powers of each State. In this case it removes the right of a State to use the land as it sees fit. It is just another case of retrospective legislation. It is a change of the rules of the game after the game has started. In Australian Rules there are two umpires but they cannot be changed at half-time, even if the team happens to be behind. It might have been a good idea in a certain game in South Australia not long ago. As a Western Australian interested in Australia and Western Australia, I am looking forward to how the Australian Democrats will vote in this case. I note their absence from the chamber. Last week while I was visiting the Pilbara, I heard Senator Jenkins on radio. She told the north-west and the Kimberleys about her interest in better eduction in the higher educational institutions up there and in more medical facilities. I entirely agree with that. But if we get the Pilbara region and the Kimberley region going on to the World Heritage List, Senator Jenkins can forget about it because there will not be people there to use these facilities.

I would like to ask the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook-he also represents the primary industries and energy portfolio in this chamber-what he told members of his Party and whether he told them exactly how it would affect his portfolio and Western Australia which he represents. I would also like to ask Senator Walsh, the famous wheat farmer from Western Australia, how it has affected his constituents. That goes for other senators I have not mentioned on the opposite benches who represent Western Australia. I ask them to tell Western Australia exactly what the Government is going to do.

I will finish on the following points. I would like to know where in this Bill there are the defined procedures for an inquiry which may lead to a World Heritage nomination. Where are the defined procedures for consultation with the States? I know that local government is not recognised in the Constitution, but I have not seen it mentioned in the Bill. Local government provides the roads and the backup facilities that are nearest to the point of action. Who will be affected during any inquiry that takes place? It is not even clear whether an inquiry is a precondition of a World Heritage listing. Is it? Where is the definition of the type of activity which the Minister may direct? He could be driving a mob of sheep over. He could be picking up samples of soil for future mining activities or prospecting. Where are the procedures for consultation before Commonwealth regulation of identified property?

Where is the right of appeal once a World Heritage nomination is made by the Commonwealth? The decision on any nomination would be totally up to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) and the 21 member countries of the World Heritage Committee. I would not like to rely on 10 or 12 of those countries to vote for the interests of Australia as there are examples of other places at other times. As I have said before, there are provisions for compensation where property is acquired by the Commonwealth, but I stress that there is no provision if the property is partly taken over, as in the case of Shark Bay, and people are left with a unit that is not viable.

Once an area is listed by UNESCO for World Heritage purposes there are no provisions for the management of that area. I have had some experience as president of a shire for five years and for 15 years I served in the same local shire. There vast areas have been taken over by what I used to call the birds and the bees but it is part of the environmental protection of certain areas. That it had taken over certain areas was advised by a simple letter to the shire. It would indicate that these areas would be taken over and that they had been marked as worthy of being preserved because of the wild life. I do not have too much beef in a lot of those cases with areas around big rocks and patches of wild flowers. There was nothing wrong with that and it was probably a good idea in the long term to have those small areas protected. But we decided to oppose the nomination of one area and we certainly got nowhere. Once the shire received a letter it was a matter of time before an area was listed. The only thing which was expended in monetary terms: was on a big 6 x 4 sign which was placed in the area stating, `This area is listed under the West Australian Wildlife Authority. You shall not move any bush, shoot any birds, shoot any rabbits, or remove any sand'. The shire could not remove gravel to put on its roads. That is as far as it used to go and nothing was done about fighting bushfires, controlling vermin that built up and went into neighbouring crops, and that sort of thing. People were liable if they shot a kangaroo going out of their crops into those protected areas. That is the sort of thing that happened in vast areas of Western Australia. Once those areas are on the World Heritage List who will manage them? Who will control the management? I have asked that question before but I have not been told.

The Press of Australia has given this Bill quite a run. I know that, over the last five years, this Government has had a good run with the media but in the last six months or so I think that has turned around slightly. At last we, on this side of politics, are getting our voices heard. It is not just people on this side of politics who are worried at this stage about what this Bill will do. The newspapers around the country have borne out what this Bill will do. For example, an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 20 May 1986, which is a fair while ago, headed, `Heritage listing move for big Outback area', states:
The proposal calls for restricted use of off-road vehicles and an end to drilling new water wells. . .
It seems that, if an area is listed, new water wells cannot be put down. The article states further:
. . . petroleum exploration could be phased out once current programs ended.
With the world running short of oil that is good news. An article in the Australian newspaper dated 14 March 1988 headed, `Conservation Bill infringes rights', states:
The Federal Government risks international censure over infringement of civil liberties, according to mining industry spokesmen.
The article goes on to state that the spokesmen claim that the legislation:
Removes the right of Australians to appeal to the High Court over World Heritage nominations.
Removes decision-making power on World Heritage listings from Australian courts . . .
Retrospectively removes grounds for legal challenges to existing World Heritage nominations.

A report in the Adelaide Advertiser on Tuesday, 14 July 1987, headed `Report urges huge SA-WA park', states that a study has recommended that about a quarter of the two States, South Australia and Western Australia, be proclaimed a national park. Another report in the Adelaide Advertiser of 7 March 1988 has the headline, `Blacks confident of land title'. So another big slab of land will be given away.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you a student of ancient history?

—I am a student of Roman history; I did not say all ancient history. The Australian Press has rightly judged what this Bill is all about. I hope that the people of Australia-especially tomorrow the people of New South Wales-will respond to what the Government is intending to do with this Bill. I seek leave to incorporate these newspaper articles in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The articles read as follows-
Advertiser, 20 May 1986
Heritage listing move for big Outback area
By Political Reporter
KYM TILBROOK
The Federal Government will be asked to support a plan to declare a vast area of SA's Outback as a World Heritage area.
The proposal, prepared by the Conservation Council of SA, covers the heartland and significant parts of the Lake Eyre drainage system.
It will be presented to the Australian Heritage Commission, in the hope of gaining Unesco recognition of the area.
The proposal calls for restricted use of off-road vehicles and an end to drilling new water wells, except where people replace bores that have failed through silting and chemical deposition.
It also says petroleum exploration could be phased out once current programs ended.
``Any finds of gas or petroleum could be strictly regulated and the current exploitation areas excluded from the World Heritage area,'' it says.
In 1974 Australia was one of the first countries to ratify the International Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage (World Heritage Convention).
The convention, adopted by the general assembly of Unesco, aims to ensure international co-operation for safeguarding the world's irreplaceable heritage.
The SA Government is examining the possibility of a World Heritage area in the Coongle Lakes area, near Innamincka, which is in the boundary of the council's proposal.

The major elements of the vast area are Lake Eyre North and Lake Eyre South, the mound springs which are natural outlets for the waters of the Great Artesian Basin, Cooper Creek and the Channel Country, and part of the Simpson Desert.
The area proposed also covers some of the world's most spectacular fossil remains at Lake Callabonna.
The SA Government last year dedicated two new national parks in the area-Mount Dare station on the SA-NT Border and Lake Eyre North and part of the adjoining Tirari Desert.
According to the Conservation Council proposal the area has a variety of aquatic life that occurs nowhere else.
``They and their surrounding ecosystems, equally unique, are survivors of a time past when the Australian continent was much wetter,'' it says.
``Careless use of the artesian waters will see it pass the way of the diprotedon and the other large Australian fauna that are now represented in the area as fossil remains.
``The area is a strange juxtaposition of arid wilderness and life supporting wetlands.''
The proposal says the mound springs have suffered considerable degradation as a result of pastoral activities since the 1800s and the sinking of bores has altered the flow rates from springs.
Another threat, according to the council, is petroleum exploration which could considerably add to the degradation of the proposed area if tighter controls are not made.

It says a number of strategies could be used in the area to provide greater protection to the environment, including stricter controls over pastoral leases through land management agreements and in some cases by exempting areas from pastoral use.
Australian, 14 March 1988
Conservation Bill `infringes rights'
The Federal Government risk international censure over infringement of civil liberties, according to mining industry spokesmen.
The mining industry claims the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill represents a major infringement of civil liberties because it gives unprecedented powers to inspectors.

The mining industry spokesmen claim that, should the Bill be passed without amendment, inspectors would have greater powers than police in that they could enter property with or without a search warrant.
They claim the legislation also:
Removes the right of Australians to appeal to the High Court over World Heritage nominations.
Removes decision-making power on World Heritage listings from Australian courts and gives sole power to the World Heritage Committee in Paris.
Retrospectively removes grounds for legal challenges to existing World Heritage nominations.
The fight for amendments is being pursued by the Australian Mining Industry Council and State chambers of mines.
Advertiser, 14 July, 1967
Report urges huge SA-WA park
by Political Reporter
KYM TILBROOK
A two-State national park covering 85,500-square kilometres on the SA-WA border may be proclaimed by the SA and WA governments.

The massive park, which would include a large section of the Nullarbor Plain in SA, has been recommended following a study by the SA National Parks and Wildlife Service, the WA Conservation and Land Management Department and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service.

The study, A Biological Survey of the Nullarbor Region South and Western Australia, also has recommended that consideration be given to proclaiming marine reserves for Southern Right whales at the Head of the Bight, and between Eyre Cove and Twilight Cove.
The whales calve off the Nullarbor coast in late winter, spring and early summer and appear to favor sheltered bays such as the Head of the Bight.

The study area of 32m hectares contains six reserves, including SA's largest park, the 2.13m hectare Unnamed Conservation Park managed by the SA NPWS, which adjoins WA's largest reserve, the 2.49m-hectare Great Victoria Desert Nature Reserve.
The SA section also covers the 231,900-hectare Nullarbor National Park.
If the proposal for the new park goes ahead, it will cover 57,961-square kilometres in SA, including 30,000-square kilometres of Crown land not now in the parks system.
The SA Minister for Environment and Planning, Dr Hopgood, said yesterday that work had begun to determine the best way of implementing the study's recommendations.
The area proposed as the two-State park was one of the largest regions of arid limestone landscape in the world and undoubtedly was of international significance.
The Australian Heritage Commission had identified the Nullarbor Plain for possible listing on the World Heritage List.

The 413-page study report says the honeycombed limestone landscape of the Nullarbor includes small blowholes, rockholes and caves, and is the only arid or semi-arid karst area of any significance in the world.
``Its caves are of international interest,'' it says.
They contain large lakes and underwater passages, important fossil deposits and significant Aboriginal sites.
The underwater passages of caves such as Cocklebiddy and Weebubbie are among the largest known and, according to the report, are unequalled for recreation anywhere in the world.
The report says the two-State park would require rangers stationed at Eucla, Cook, Nullarbor and Cocklebiddy.
This would allow it to be managed as one of Australia's ``premier conservation areas''.
Advertiser, 7 March, 1988
Blacks confident of land title
Aborigines in SA's north-west are likely to be given freehold title by the end of the year to the 21,362-square-kilometre Unnamed Conservation Park-one of the largest parks in the world.
The proposal, which is almost certain to go ahead, will give Aborigines title to about 21 p.c. of the State.

The park, which meets the SA-WA border, is locked between the vast Pitjantjatjara homelands and the Maralinga homelands and would give Aborigines title to 200,792 square kilometres of the north-west of the State.

The director-general of the Department of Environment and Planning, Dr Ian McPhail, said yesterday negotiations had ``proved to be very positive'' and he hoped for a good outcome by the end of the year.
He said officers from the department, Maralinga Aborigines and the SA National Parks and Wildlife Service were discussing a plan whereby the Maralinga people would lease the park back to the NPWS.
Dr McPhail said SA already had a very successful Aboriginal ranger training program and if the proposal went ahead he hoped most of the rangers at the park would be Aborigines.
The legal representative for the Maralinga Aborigines, Mr Darcy O'Shea, said yesterday the elders were also confident they would be given title by the end of the year.
He said the Maralinga Aborigines already considered it their land as they had been born on the land and grown up on it. ``It's their whole social and cultural structure and fabric,'' he said.
``It's legal recognition of their ownership of it. They feel responsible towards that land and the best way they can discharge that responsibility is to have title and a say over it''.
Dr McPhail said the park was a `perfect wilderness' and one of the most magnificent areas of arid desert vegetation in the world.
The transfer would require the approval of the SA Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been so many furphies or, to give the benefit of the doubt to the Opposition, misconceptions floated in this debate about the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 that it would be absolutely impossible for me in half an hour to cover them all. I will try to do justice to the nonsense that Senator Panizza has just delivered. I started noting the points he was making that were incorrect, but I ran out of paper. I hope the honourable senator will forgive me if I do not cover all the points he made. Because of the large number of speakers in this debate so far, it is appropriate that I at least concentrate on the shadow Minister for the Environment, Senator Puplick, and give him some precedence. I was astonished at the facile nature of his contribution to this debate, the lack of grasp he has of the real issues that are involved in this legislation and how it will operate. I will try to address some of the points raised by Senator Panizza. I am sure that if I do not other speakers who will follow me will do so.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to Senator Puplick's contribution. He opened by saying:

The Bill represents, on the part of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Government, an admission of their failure to make the federal system work and their inability to deal with the constituent States of the Australian Federation in a proper and civilised fashion.

That simply assumes that the federal system operates as a one-way street. The difficulty with cooperating with the Queensland Government is very simple. The Australian Government wants to preserve the rainforests of Australia in the national interest and the Queensland Government wants to cut them down.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is totally untrue, Senator. It is a total misrepresentation.

—I see that Senator Stone is on the speakers list; his turn will come. Senator Alston carried on with the same nonsense. He said that this legislation will not advance the cause of conservation. I have some factual dispute with that because the point at issue between the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth is that this legislation will prevent the Queensland Government allowing trees to be cut down in rainforests. The Queensland Government wants to cut them down. That is the point on the public record at issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to what Senator Puplick had to say about the High Court of Australia. We can hardly blame speakers like Senator Panizza for totally misunderstanding the role of the High Court in this matter if the shadow Minister himself does not have the slightest idea what he is talking about. Senator Puplick put a most curious argument, and is recorded in Hansard. He quoted in a number of places from a judgment of the High Court relating to the recent action that has taken place. He quoted from the judgments of Mr Justice Mason and Mr Justice Brennan on the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests legislation, saying that they asserted that the Commonwealth does have the right to move for interim protection of areas nominated for World Heritage listing. He went on to say:

The important thing to understand about this is that the High Court of Australia, in fact, has said that the power which the Government claims it needs to put into legislation is a power which is already there.

The nonsense of that argument, as I intend to demonstrate shortly, is that the composition of the High Court changes, and so do its judgments and its general attitude towards this most vexed question of Federal and State powers. This legislation simply puts into legislative effect the judgment that has been made by the High Court. Senator Puplick has simply turned the argument on its head and made a nonsense of it. The High Court says that the Government does have this power. This legislation simply affirms the judgment of the High Court and, therefore, on Senator Puplick's own argument, the Opposition should be supporting it and not opposing it.

A gross misunderstanding of Senator Puplick, the shadow Minister for the Environment, about the role of the High Court is exhibited by his statement-I must say that just about every speaker in the Opposition followed the line laid down by him when he was talking about the High Court-that this legislation is going to remove the jurisdiction of the High Court over these matters. Senator Puplick, in respect of the role of the High Court, said:

We have vast paraphernalia put into the legislation that will remove from the jurisdiction of Australian courts the right to make determinations about the validity of nominations or, indeed, about the quality and worth of the nominations.

It is about time that that appalling misunderstanding of the role of the High Court was put to rest. I cannot do any better to put it to rest than to quote from the excellent book Encounters with the Australian Constitution by Michael Coper. He says it better than I can. Michael Coper, on page 37 of his book, says this about the Franklin Dam case:

Yet the public perception appeared to be perhaps inevitably, that the High Court was called upon to decide not merely which government had the right to decide whether a dam would be built on the Gordon River, but the substantive question of whether the dam should or should not be built. Such misconceptions are not merely the natural products of untutored minds; they are deliberately fostered from time to time by those with a vested interest in doing so.
I will leave it up to honourable senators to decide whether Senator Puplick has an untutored mind or a vested interest. Michael Coper went on:

In 1975, for example, in the only major reversal suffered by the Whitlam government at the hands of the High Court, the Court held to be invalid the Commonwealth's Petroleum and Minerals Authority Act of 1973 (Victoria v Commonwealth). The reason was that the Act had failed to comply with the procedural requirements in section 57 of the Constitution relating to the resolution of deadlocks between the two Houses of the federal Parliament. Mr Joh Bjelke-Petersen, Queensland Premier and bete noire of central governments of any complexion, greeted the decision with glee: `At last,' he exclaimed, ``the High Court has said to the Commonwealth, `keep your hands off mining'.'' The High Court has of course, said nothing of the sort. The Act was invalid for reasons which were totally unrelated to the content of the Act. The decision has nothing whatever to do with the question of whether it was within the power of the Commonwealth to legislate about mining, and certainly nothing to do with the question of whether the Commonwealth should legislate about mining, a question which is scarcely any business of the High Court.

Similarly, the question in the Franklin Dam case was not, and could not have been, whether or not the dam was a good thing, or whether the better policy was conservation or development. But perhaps because of the public perception of what had become a very high-profile and intensely political controversy the High Court took the unusual step of issuing with the judgments a separate statement strongly denying the relevance of the merits of the dispute to the constitutional issue which had to be decided.

I cannot say it any better than that. I refer honourable senators who have put about these furphies concerning the High Court's role to that section of Coper's book. I cannot deny honourable senators the opportunity of listening to Coper's reference to a very well known case before the High Court which determined the extent of Federal powers in overriding State powers-the Clyde Engineering case. A justice of the High Court in his judgment made a statement about his views of the distinction between the Federal power and the State power. I stress, this is a judgment, of a justice of the High Court. Mr Justice Higgins said:

The State Law is like the Nile River, which covers the whole area with its flood, except that part of the area which is appropriated to the villages. The State law fills, as it were, all the sponge except the fibre.

Anyone who can make any sense out of that is a better man than I am, Gunga Din. So many honourable senators opposite spent some time following the nonsense that Senator Puplick started that there has been a complete misunderstanding of the role of the High Court and this legislation. It is constitutionally impossible for this Parliament to remove from the High Court the right to review this Parliament's legislation in terms of the High Court's role in the matter, that is, to test its constitutional validity. There is nothing whatever in this legislation to prevent the Queensland Government or, indeed, any other government, taking the legislation which we are currently debating to the High Court and having the High Court test its validity.

The nonsense that Senator Panizza has just repeated, that this legislation removes the right of the High Court to review these matters, has to be put to rest once and for all. The fact is that it should not be the role of the High Court of Australia to make a biological assessment of the worth or otherwise of applications before the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO) for World Heritage listing. I do not deny that the combined wisdom of the High Court is certainly capable of doing so, but it is not the proper role of the High Court. It is the proper role of UNESCO to make that judgment.

I move on to a second furphy that has been run by honourable senators opposite-that the referral of a listing to UNESCO is an abrogation of Australian sovereignty. What absolute nonsense that is. It is suggested that UNESCO, an overseas body, will make a decision which profoundly affects Australia. It will not make any decision at all unless it receives an application to do so from the properly elected and sovereign Australian Government of the day. It is obvious that, should a government, of whatever political persuasion, choose to take matters for listing to UNESCO, as I have no doubt a Liberal-National Party coalition government would do in some cases, it would simply mean that the Government of Australia had determined in the first instance that the properties concerned should be listed on the World Heritage List. Therefore, again, these silly arguments about abrogating Australia's sovereignty have to be put to rest.

In passing, Senator Alston made an extraordinary comment about which I intend to ask him at some stage when he is back in the chamber. Perhaps he can explain it to me. One of the other furphies that has been run in this debate concerns the entire question of inspectorial powers. I know that other speakers will take this up in more detail later in the debate but, from the work I have done over many years in respect of delegated legislation, where a great many of these powers reside, I can assure honourable senators that they would be amazed at some of the things that inspectors can do under all kinds of Acts.
Senate Maguire-Tell us about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not intend to tell honourable senators about it; other speakers will. But I will tell honourable senators one thing that inspectors cannot do. As far as I know, at least under legislation-this appeared to be the inference-they cannot corrupt judges. I cannot understand on what basis Senator Alston said that under this Bill inspectors will be corrupting the judiciary. I would like to know which part of the legislation he was referring to when he made that statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick also had the hide to suggest that Territorians were going to be specifically disadvantaged by this legislation in respect of compensation for World Heritage listing that may be made in the Northern Territory. Senator Puplick, as shadow Minister for the environment, has no excuse for this most extraordinary misunderstanding of the provisions of this legislation, because, in fact, the legislation in respect of the Northern Territory does exactly the reverse. Senator Puplick referred to the Teori Tau case in 1969 which determined-I am quoting from Senator Puplick's speech-that `the Commonwealth is not obliged to provide just terms for the acquisition of property which takes place within the Territory which they represent'. He then went on to say:

But there is no attempt in this Bill to address that particular matter. The Bill simply states that if there is an acquisition of property it shall have the same meaning and be done on the same terms as paragraph 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia.

In fact, Senator Puplick is profoundly wrong. The Bill, when it talks about compensation, does say that `just terms' has the same meaning in paragraph 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. It goes on to say that people are entitled to receive compensation. That provision, constitutionally, extends as well to the people of the Northern Territory.

What section 122 of the Constitution says, and what the High Court of Australia determined it said in the case mentioned by Senator Puplick, is that where a specific provision is made by the Commonwealth in respect of the Northern Territory which may put it at odds with the rest of Australia, the Commonwealth has the power to do that under section 122 of the Constitution. But for this legislation to bring about the situation which Senator Puplick asserted that it did, there would have to be a specific reference in this legislation excluding the Northern Territory from the provision of compensation contained in this legislation. There is in fact no such exemption in this legislation. The fact is that in terms of just compensation, this particular piece of legislation advances the cause and the position of the people in the Northern Territory, not disadvantages it, as Senator Puplick would hold.

The other startling misunderstanding of this legislation came when honourable senators opposite suggested that the legislation removed the application of the Freedom of Information Act in terms of how the inspectors will operate. Really, I would suggest that honourable senators opposite have some obligation to do at least a little basic research if they are going to debate pieces of legislation before the House. Proposed new section 17c (4) of the Bill states:
Section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 does not apply in relation to information or documents to which this section applies-

that is, the confidentiality section involving the material that inspectors gather in the course of their work. The fact is that section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act deals with secrecy provisions in other Acts and allows exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act. In other words, proposed new section 17c (4) of this legislation preserves the right, rather than weakens it, for freedom of information access. It is absolutely clear that section 38 of the Freedom of Information Act does not apply to information collected by the inspectors. The Opposition has totally misread this legislation. In exactly the same way, the Opposition has made statements about the High Court, but it has turned the meaning of proposed new section 17c (4) on its head. This proposed new section, in fact, means that the information will be available under the Freedom of Information Act, not, as the Opposition would hold, that it will not be available.
I would like to turn to the contribution that was made to this debate by Senator Boswell, because once again he has run a number of other furphies. Senator Boswell opened his contribution by saying:
Tonight the Senate is debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988.
I responded:
That is the only thing you will get right.
It turned out that that was the case. Senator Boswell went on to say that this legislation:
will take the right to decide the fate of our Constitution away from the High Court of Australia . . .
I believe that I have adequately dealt with that matter. Senator Boswell said:
. . . I invite Senator Collins to get up and say so-because he will not.
On this issue, I intend to take Senator Boswell head on.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be an irresistible force meeting an immovable object.

—When I say `head on', I am probably giving Senator Boswell the benefit of the doubt. Senator Boswell went on to say that the determination of the listing by UNESCO was an abrogation of Australian sovereignty. I have dealt with that matter as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to a far more serious accusation that Senator Boswell made. Senator Boswell said that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists who examined the material produced by the Queensland Government, and adversely reported upon it, did so because they were coerced and intimidated in coming to their scientific conclusions by the Federal Government. That astounded me. I worked for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation before I came into politics. Having worked with CSIRO scientists for a number of years in Kakadu National Park, I know that the one thing they place above all other things is their professional integrity. If I had to pick one organisation in Australia where the people working within it would be less subject to and less likely to respond to coercion or intimidation, it would be the CSIRO.

TALK.START.PARA: —Try working for Graham Richardson, Senator.
—If Senator Stone really wants to follow Senator Boswell down this path, I would warn him to be a little bit careful before he jumps in.
—He should check his facts.

—In response to that interjection from Senator Maguire, I did in fact take the trouble to do what Senator Boswell clearly did not. I checked my facts. In fact, I contacted the scientists concerned. I put to them what Senator Boswell had said about their critical analysis of the Queensland Government's information. They told me in very graphic terms what they thought about Senator Boswell's assertion.
—Who are `they'?

—The scientists-the honourable senator obviously has not been following the debate at all. If he wants to contribute to this debate, at least he should have the courtesy to follow the issues. I will say it again: I contacted the CSIRO scientists who were--
—No names. Faceless men.

—Shirley, you really are a monumental pain in the neck. I contacted the CSIRO scientists who prepared the analysis of the information provided by the Queensland Government. That is public information, Senator. If Senator Walters knew the slightest thing about this matter, she would know who they are, but for her benefit I will name them. I was not going to because I did not see the necessity. They were Dr Mike Hopkins and Geoff Tracey, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation scientists who prepared a critical analysis of the Queensland Government's information. I then contacted, as I felt I had an obligation to do, the Chief of the Division for which they work in Canberra and he told me what the facts were. When the information was produced by the Queensland Government as to the extent or otherwise of the logging in north Queensland over which there was a dispute, the then Department of Arts, Heritage and the Environment went to CSIRO. In the same way that it could have gone to any other professional consultant organisation in the area, it went to CSIRO because the scientists concerned had a national reputation for knowing more about rainforests than probably anyone else in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department asked CSIRO, as research consultants, to carry out an investigation of this information and produce a report. CSIRO took on that job as a professional consultancy from the Department and was paid for it accordingly. There was no coercion or intimidation or political pressure from anyone. CSIRO did a piece of professional research work, which indeed is its charter, and did it very well. Senator Boswell, having falsely maligned the professional integrity of the CSIRO scientists concerned, as I have just demonstrated, would prefer to rely instead on the scientific validity of the information produced by the organisation known as the Northern Rainforest Management Agency (NORMA), which was set up by the Queensland Government. Indeed, there have been a number of references to it already during this debate. NORMA was set up allegedly to provide the same kind of impartial scientific advice on whether or not these rainforest areas deserve to be listed on the World Heritage List as CSIRO indeed did. The interesting thing about NORMA -it is worthwhile looking at this-is that this impartial and non-biased organisation that was going to determine whether the listing should go ahead placed the following advertisement mentioned in the Port Douglas and Mosman Gazette of 25 February, announcing that it was going to hold public meetings in Innisfail:
Come and hear the latest report on the vital work of NORMA's Scientific Committee opposed to World Heritage Listing of our rainforest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hardly impartial.

—Hardly. NORMA was a little embarrassed, a little upset about this, and said that in fact there had been a clerical error. The only problem was that NORMA had also committed a fairly gross clerical error in the circular that was sent to all of the news editors announcing the conference. The circular said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the morning session would be open to the press but the afternoon session would be closed to discuss tactics to `oppose' the listing for world heritage.

That is from an organisation which purports to be producing a scientific and detached analysis of whether the listing should go ahead. So that honourable senators do not misunderstand me, I am not criticising the scientists who worked on the report for NORMA; those errors were made by the political masters that were running the show. That is why 25 eminent scientists, expert in rainforests, refused to act for NORMA, refused to work for it. They feared that the Queensland Government would do precisely what it did. Despite all of that, the NORMA report concluded:

(1) Queensland's High Court Challenge is partly based on the grounds that substantial nominated areas are not of World Heritage significance. However, the scientific committee's report could only find 23,700 hectares, or 2.5% of the nominated area, as having a `low conservation priority'.
(2) The report also identified 84,000 hectares of rainforest with the `highest conservation priority' which had not been included in the nomination.

*The report found that of the 167,000 hectares of rainforest allocated for logging by the Queensland Forestry Department, about 126,000 hectares or three-quarters of this area was of such high conservation significance that it should not be logged. This would reduce the timber industry to 30% of its current levels.
Of the four scenarios NORMA examined:

*Even the land-use scenario most biased in favour of the timber industry predicted it would have to be slashed to half its 1987 level. This would involve logging in areas with marginal timber prospects and high to moderate conservation values.

So despite the fact that as far as the Queensland Government was concerned it was a set-up, the Committee came down with such a favourable report for World Heritage listing. The Queensland Minister responsible for the environment is now trying to disown it by saying that it is only a preliminary study because the leakage of the document has profoundly embarrassed the Queensland Government.

The substance of this debate in fact is very simple. The Federal Government has introduced this legislation because of the failure of attempts to persuade the Queensland Government to co-operate in the national interest to save those rainforests.

—Senator Boswell wants to ruin the place and this Government wants to preserve it.
