SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which quite unnecessarily and undesirably extends the Commonwealth's powers in Word Heritage matters and it further intrudes and tramples on the rights and the intrinsic responsibilities of the Australian States through the pernicious use of the external affairs powers. It is clear that the legislation will have long term general application.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill was introduced with the nomination of the Queensland wet tropics region in mind. By proposed new section 3a this Bill seeks to give the Commonwealth power to afford interim protection in respect of identified property, that is, property which is only subject to World Heritage List nomination, or which is merely subject to an inquiry to determine whether the property forms part of the cultural or natural heritage.

Regrettably, the High Court of Australia last week declared valid the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests (Commission of Inquiry) Act, which prohibits logging in those two areas pending the outcome of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. That is the inevitable result of using external affairs powers in such a pernicious way.

With the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill the Hawke Government is repeating the dose, and this time Queensland is on the receiving end. To rub salt into the wound, the Federal Government's actions come on top of previous commitments pursuing unilateral action when nominating sites for World Heritage listing. At the July 1984 meeting of the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers procedures were agree upon which were to occur before a site in Australia was to be nominated for World Heritage listing. The agreement provided for, at that time, full consultation between the Commonwealth and the States or the Territory concerned. It also included the statement:
The Commonwealth Government has indicated that it will not take unilateral action to nominate areas for World Heritage listing without the agreement of the State or Territory concerned.
Further, on 12 September 1984, Mr Hawke wrote to the then Queensland Premier stating:
It is not the intention of my Government to take unilateral action to nominate the region for World Heritage listing.

Of course, it is the situation of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests all over again. Honourable senators will recall that the Hawke Government abrogated a formal agreement also signed at that meeting. In that case it was an agreement between the Tasmanian and Commonwealth governments over the consultative process that would be applied to planning in National Estate forests. The Commonwealth reneged on that agreement not nine months after it was signed on behalf of the Commonwealth by the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin. The Government also confirmed its bilateral commitment to World Heritage listing through Senator Ryan on behalf of the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. On 11 February 1986 Senator Ryan advised the Senate:

The Government has made it clear that the wet tropic rainforests of north-east Queensland will only be nominated for inclusion on the World Heritage List with the agreement of the Queensland Government. The Government is of the view that a co-operative, not confrontationist, approach is the best way of conserving Australia's rainforest resources. The co-operation achieved with the Queensland Government in the preparation of the Working Group Report is an indication of the fruitlessness of that approach.

So much for those fine old words and for the Hawke Government's spirit of co-operation. As is so often the case, the Government's actions are not matched by its rhetoric and the history of the wet tropics nomination tells the true story.

The Commonwealth's decision to proceed with the nomination was announced-as is inevitably the case with this Government-in a Press statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 5 June 1987. This announcement was made without prior consultation with the Queensland Government or those directly affected by the World Heritage listing. The formal advice of the decision to proceed was not given to the Queensland Government until 23 June, notwithstanding the fact that a public Press statement had been made on 5 June. On 17 August the then Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, announced a consultation period in relation to the proposed nomination, the purpose of which was for the Federal Government to find out about proposed projects for the area and assess them in light of the proposed listing. The Minister allowed only until 22 October for the preparation and submission of objections and comments on the proposed listing. Late in September the Minister confirmed that logging would be unconditionally forbidden in the proposed World Heritage area. In December the Minister pronounced the area to be nominated for listing. This area comprises 9,200 square kilometres of north Queensland tropical rainforest, stretching from just north of Townsville almost to Cooktown. It includes State forest, timber reserve, national park and other crown land and also about 100 square kilometres of privately owned land.

The Hawke Government has again acted completely arbitrarily in its decision to proceed with that nomination. Not only has it chosen to proceed without calling for State and local government or industry reaction to the proposal, but also its decision to ban logging without a proper assessment of the social and economic ramifications can only be judged as ham-fisted and totally inappropriate. The Government's approach in banning all logging operations also appears at variance with the national conservation strategy which was accepted and adopted by the Federal Government in 1983. The national conservation strategy for Australia stated as an essential element:

Conservation and development are fundamentally linked by their dependence on living resources . . . to provide for today's needs as well as to conserve the living stock for tomorrow, both conservation and development are necessary.

I turn now to the particular details of the Bill. As I mentioned previously, clause 5 proposes a new section 3a which seeks to amend the definition of `identified property' to which protection may be extended by a proclamation made under the principal Act. Ostensibly, the amendments are made-to quote the explanatory memorandum:
to follow more closely the procedures which the Convention . . . requires Australia to follow in protecting properties of cultural or natural heritage as defined in the Convention.
I quote now from the second reading speech:
In other words, the Act would follow the three stages of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage: identification of property, nomination and listing.

However, it is clear that the unstated, although I am sure intended, effect of these amendments to the definition of `identified property' is to further deprive persons affected by any proposed listing of their ultimate and intrinsic right to challenge in the High Court of Australia the validity of any disruption to their otherwise lawful activities. Owing to recent High Court decisions it is now quite clear that the actual process of nominating sites to the World Heritage List is no longer reviewable because it involves the making of a Cabinet decision.

The effect of the Bill before us is to take away a person's final recourse to the High Court and to place firmly once and for all in the hands of a committee sitting in Paris the sole power over matters affecting our cultural and natural heritage. This committee, which administers the World Heritage Convention, comprises 21 of the 100 signatories to the convention. Currently, by chance, Australia is a member of the committee, but in the future this may not necessarily always apply. Accordingly, it is highly likely that the fate of industries and jobs in Australia will ultimately be decided by a committee of foreign countries; yet the owners of those industries or those jobs will not be able to make out a case in the courts of this land for protection from the Australian government's decision affecting their very livelihood. That is a very sad reflection on and a damning indictment of this Labor Government. But of course it is the inevitable and obvious price one has to pay for the use of external affairs powers in this way.

Another matter of grave concern relates to the powers given under the Bill to the inspectors appointed by the Minister. Proposed section 17a of the Act allows an inspector to enter and search an eligible place or inspect and take photographs or measurements of an eligible thing if that inspector is acting for an eligible purpose. In simple English, this means that an inspector can enter any land, building or structure, except for a dwelling house, whether it is on identified property or not, or any vehicle to determine whether an unlawful act has or will be done in relation to the identified property. Therefore, the powers given to inspectors are wide.

Even more unacceptable is the fact that in certain circumstances these inspectors are empowered to dispense with the need for the consent of the owners or for the need to obtain a warrant from an appointed judge. By any mea-sure the conditions of entry are quite subjective. The inspector must believe on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to enter to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of any thing. Honourable senators will note that the Bill does not say `any eligible thing' which is to be prescribed by the regulations, but `any thing'. The measurement or yardstick is that entry must be made in circumstances of `seriousness and urgency' in the mind of the inspector. It is clear that the powers given to inspectors have the potential to be a gross intrusion on any person's privacy. Honourable senators must be aware that inspectors are given power to enter any land, building or structure anywhere in Australia-not just on identified property. Further, they can stop, detain, enter and search any vehicle anywhere in Australia. Unlike Dr Blewett, I do not believe that privacy is a bourgeois right; I believe it to be the prerogative of every Australian to be protected from unwarranted intrusion. For example, I believe in the inalienable right of the citizen to be protected from intrusion into his home, place of business or when driving a motor vehicle.

The powers given to inspectors are wider than those given to the police in most instances and have the potential to be subject to grave misuse and abuse. Further, the so-called safeguards on entry without consent or warrant are quite meaningless in the face of an inspector who merely states his belief that entry is necessary in the circumstances. Even where the circumstances are not particularly urgent, how many Australians would be so confident in their knowledge of the law when faced with an inspector who presents an identification card to have the courage to refuse their consent to a search? Even should a person choose to refuse consent in the mistaken belief that an inspector had no power to enter his property without his consent or without a warrant, he could find himself liable to prosecution and a fine of $1,000 or 12 months imprisonment. Of course these provisions are fraught with difficulties and considerable danger.

My final comment on the provisions of the Bill relate to part III, which provides that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 shall not apply to the World Heritage legislation or the submission of property for World Heritage listing. This Act permits, of course, Commonwealth involvement in environmental assessment by two means-by way of the inquiry section and also the environmental impact statement (EIS) section. The object of the Act is to ensure that matters affecting the Commonwealth to a significant extent are fully examined and taken into account in and in relation to, amongst other things, the carrying out of works and other projects and the making of decisions and recommendations, as found in section 5.

In general terms, the Act allows the environmental assessment of the activities of the Commonwealth and others where Commonwealth approval is required for such activities where these activities do or are likely to affect the environment. By so limiting the operation of this legislation the present Bill has given the Minister an unfettered and quite unlimited discretion either to approve or to reject proposed acts or projects in world heritage areas without the need to have recourse to inquiries or studies which would examine the benefits or otherwise of these projects. Once again the Hawke Government has seen fit to give Ministers total power to judge whether or not a project should go ahead in a listed area. Of course the considerations on which the Minister's decision will be made are unknown but will it be certain, knowing the pragmatism of this Government, that it will not be on environmental grounds or on the merits of a particular proposal. My guess is that what will be the objective measure or test of the Minister will be what is acceptable to the voters. This, of course, was the determining factor, in the case of the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests legislation.

One further draconian aspect of the Government's decision to dispense with the need for the EIS legislation is that it is slated to operate retrospectively. This provision in the Bill is to take effect `as if it had commenced on the commencement of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act of 1983'. I have always been and will continue to be totally opposed to the retrospective use of legislation. In the present case the Government has used the device solely for the purpose of frustrating appeals to the High Court of Australia on current heritage proposals, as it has also done through its trick of repealing certain regulations made in relation to the wet tropics in order to replace them with identical regulations under this proposed Act. The Government ought to stand condemned for its sly and underhanded tactics used solely to try to clear up the dreadful mess it has made with its handling of the wet tropics nomination.

I conclude my remarks by saying now, as I have said many times in the past, that it is clear to all of us that the States are far better equipped than the Commonwealth to undertake environmental activities. The very basis of the principle of the devolution of power from the Commonwealth to the States and down through local government is that the best and most effective form of administration is that which is closest to the people. I referred previously to the first of the strategic principles set forth in the 1983 national conservation strategy document which emphasised the integration of conservation and development, and their interdependence and common ground. This task of integration must surely fall to the States as it is clear that the ownership and control of natural resources within their boundaries lies to a substantial degree with the respective State governments.

The present Federal Government has shown its effectiveness at preventing development, as the Tasmanian dams case clearly illustrates. However, it has not demonstrated any capacity to integrate and formulate development activities with the needs of conservation. We need only look to the stalling of the national rainforest conservation program for evidence of that. In June of 1986 the then Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment, Barry Cohen, announced that the Government had adopted this rainforest program as proposed by the 1985 working group and had agreed to provide $22.25m for the program over the following two financial years. Negotiations with the States were to commence immediately and now, nearing the end of the two-year period, Queensland, with around 60 per cent of Australia's rainforests, still has not received any of those funds owing to the Commonwealth's insistence of the quid pro quo that logging cease.

By fulfilling its obligation to provide funds under this program the Federal Government would do more to assist in genuine rainforest conservation than by proceeding with the present legislation. It is clear that the States have both the incentive and the opportunity to formulate arrangements to ensure the integration of conservation and development. Until the Labor Government realises this, its environmental policy will fail.

To me, the sadness of this debate is that anybody who argues against domestic legislation which is introduced as an extension of the World Heritage Convention is judged immediately as being anti-conservation. Of course that is a totally arrogant position and it is by any measure intellectually dishonest, but it is typical of the crude fraud of these fringe groups which claim that they have an exclusive mortgage on the care of all things conservation. I hope that commonsense will prevail in the Australian Democrats and that they will join with us in defeating this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a Bill to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the Environment Protection Act 1974. If the people of Australia had only been given time to be aware of what this Bill contains the demonstrations over the identity card would have had nothing on the demonstrations that would now be taking place in Australia against this Bill. The Bill takes away more of the rights of the individual than any other Bill has ever done. I believe it is the most draconian Bill ever to come before the Senate. But is has been brought in by a government which believes in that sort of thing. I will quote from one of its Ministers because it is important that the people of Australia understand what this Government believes. To the South Australian Labor Conference in June 1986 the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say as a socialist that it is the interests of the community that should come before the individual right . . . we should't get too hung up as socialists on privacy because privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property.
That is what this Government believes are the rights of the individual. The rights of the state overcome the rights of the individual in every piece of legislation it brings before the Senate.

Let us see what is the aim of this Bill according to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). I stress the words `according to the Minister'. According to Senator Richardson, the aim is to strengthen the present legislation to protect World Heritage areas. He intends to redefine the definition of `identified property', that is, property which the Government believes may be of World Heritage value, to bring it more in line with the definition in the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and National Heritage. I repeat that such a property will be redefined according to the World Heritage Convention, that is, not defined in the Australian way but in the way of overseas countries. The Minister also says that the Bill will allow any part of that property to be proclaimed-not the total property but any small part of it-and be subject to ministerial direction as to its use and so called protection. The Bill will freeze the use of a property if the property is nominated as having World Heritage value or if an inquiry is pending to determine the potential of a property for World Heritage value. While there is a time limit on this freeze, it is virtually unlimited; I will come to that later.

The Bill also sets up a system of inspectors for World Heritage properties. I will come to what those inspectors can do later. We are also told that under certain circumstances Commonwealth compensation will be given and that there will be penalties for breaches of confidentiality. There will also be no requirement for an environmental impact statement on ministerial approved projects. Retrospectively, the Bill changes the right of Queensland to appeal to the High Court, as it is doing at the moment; a State will be able to appeal only to the international committee if areas within that State are nominated by the Government.

Let us look at what this does because it is most important that we understand what the Minister is really doing. Let us look at the question of identified properties. The first change is that the Bill refers to freezing the use of any property that is subject to an inquiry. At the moment the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests is going on in Tasmania. The Helsham inquiry has already said that logging can continue in parts of Tasmania that are part of that inquiry. But, under this legislation, the Helsham inquiry would not be able to do that. Under this legislation, because an inquiry had been instigated, even that sort of area of land would be frozen, according to the Bill, until 42 days after the final report; so the Helsham inquiry in our State would have been thwarted by this legislation. So any property subject to an inquiry will be frozen. An inquiry can take any length of time; there is nothing in the Bill that says that an inquiry must be undertaken within a reasonable time. So a whole area in a State can be frozen for any length of time. An inquiry could take place over five years and property could be frozen for five years, and 42 days after the final report is brought down. Nothing in this Bill stops that occurring.

I move to the second point. The use of a property can be frozen if it is the subject of a nomination for the World Heritage List. So, even if a property is nominated-not listed-everything must stop. The World Heritage Committee takes quite a time to look at nominations and so that freeze could go on for a considerable time.
The third point is that the freeze can occur if a property is included on the World Heritage List. That is not so bad; once it is on the list, that is fair enough.

The fourth point, and perhaps the most draconian of all, is that not even a nomination or inquiry is needed, but just a regulation by the Minister to say that a property forms part of the cultural or national heritage. This can be declared in a regulation. I believe that is the most draconian of all parts, and this is what the Minister is all about. Let Australians beware that, by the Minister putting forward a regulation, whole areas of their State can be set aside, and for any length of time.

Under the legislation not just any judge will be able to issue a warrant; but I will come back to that in a moment when I refer to the inspectors. I turn now to compensation. The Bill states that, where the Commonwealth acquires property to go on the list, it is liable to pay compensation of a reasonable amount to the owner of the property. But the Bill goes on to say that, where the Commonwealth and the owner cannot agree on what is a reasonable amount, the owner can take the Commonwealth to the Federal courts to decide. But who will pay the costs? Who can afford to take the Federal Government to the courts to institute proceedings for recovery from the Commonwealth of an amount considered reasonable? What will happen to a mining area where perhaps exploration is just starting and the Government decides, `No, we will freeze that under a regulation'. What occurs then? Who determines what a reasonable cost is? How can a mining company or the Government know what is under the ground? How would we have any idea what a reasonable cost is?

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you compensate?
—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, how do we compensate a company for the amount of exploration that has already gone on?

SPEECH.PARA: Now to inspectors. The inspectors can enter a property at any time of the night or day without a warrant, if they believe that it is urgent for them to do so. They can enter and search; however, they cannot go into a person's home. They can go onto a person's property. They can stop a vehicle and search it. A person is meant to be able to identify them because they will be able to produce an identification card. I can assure you, Mr Deputy President, that if I, as a woman, was in my car on a dark night and was flagged down by an inspector who showed me his identification card through my window, I would not take notice of that. I would not open the door to let in a strange man to inspect the interior of my car. I can assure the Minister for Resources, who is at the table, that I would not do that. I would incur a penalty of $1,000 for not doing so. I would have to pay $1,000 because I had refused, at midnight or later, to open the door of my car to a strange man who flashed some sort of identification at me. How would I know that it was a legitimate request? How would I know, in an isolated country area, that an inspector who flashed a card at me and said, `Open your door, Madam', was legitimate? If I did not do that I would be charged $1,000.

Let us look at the penalty for a person who is no longer an inspector and has not handed in his identification card. The person I am talking about may have been relieved of his duties, because he has abused them. He may even have accosted a female; we would not know. The penalty for that inspector not handing in his identification card is $100. He would be charged $100 and I would be charged $1,000 for refusing to open the door of my car to such a bloke. The penalty is not just $1,000; it is $1,000 or imprisonment for 12 months or both. This Government, in its search for community interests over individual rights, brings in such draconian legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That argument is logically defective and you know it.
—Why does the Minister say that?
—What you are citing is a maximum penalty which may be applied in the event of a conviction.

—What I am citing is the maximum penalty for refusing to open the door to an inspector, which is $1,000. What I am also citing is the maximum penalty for an inspector who does not hand in his ID card and is acting unlawfully, which is $100. Do not let the Minister say that I am not speaking the truth. This Bill is the Minister's legislation and he has to act in accordance with it. As I have already said, the Government's policy is, and I again quote the Minister, `Let me say as a socialist that the interests of the community come before individual rights'. I will quote that on every occasion I can possibly do so. That is the Government's policy regarding individual rights. As I have said, the inspectors can go on to a person's property at any time of the day or the night without a warrant. But if they do bring a warrant they bring one from only certain judges-those chosen by the Minister. They are not obtained from any Federal Court judge; just certain judges. They can be pet judges-those whom the Government and the Minister decide are the Government's little mates. If the people of Australia were aware of the sort of legislation that we have before us, the demonstrations against the ID card would bear no relation to what would happen here.

SPEECH.PARA: After telling us that the inspectors can do anything they like-they can go onto a property, take photographs, record, inspect and measure up things and stop and detain a person; all without a warrant if they decide that it is a matter of urgency-the Government turns to confidentiality. It is a joke for this Government to put anything about confidentiality in legislation because when the Government was caught breaking the confidentiality laws, the Minister concerned, the Minister for Community Services and Health said, `It was not me; it was my staff. I did not know about it. My Department handed on confidential information to my staff who handed it out to back bench committees, thereby identifying people and breaking the law. But I did not do that. I am the Minister and I did not actually see that. I only gave a direction that it be handed out. I did not actually see it, so I am not to blame'. Where does the buck stop in this Government? It has stated in this legislation that there should be confidentiality, but we know of Dr Blewett's lack of confidentiality. We know that under this Government on at least four separate occasions the Health Insurance Commission has breached the act of confidentiality. On each occasion the Minister for Community Services and Health refused to accept responsibility for it.

Where does the buck stop in this Government in terms of confidentiality? It puts it in legislation and it does not abide by it; yet it puts it in additional legislation. That is a laugh. People do not believe the Government. They believe that there is no need for it. Dr Blewett said that privacy, in many ways, is a bourgeois right which is very much associated with the right to private property. That is what the Minister thinks about the need for privacy and confidentiality. The Bill refers to confidentiality; yet the Minister says that confidentiality or privacy is a bourgeois right that is very much associated with the right to private property. That is what this Government thinks of confidentiality; yet it continues to put it in legislation. What absolute rubbish we have before us today. If only the people of Australia had had time to realise what sort of legislation this is, they would have risen in wrath as they did with the ID card.

The legislation states that there is no longer any need for an environmental impact statement. It will change the existing legislation to say that it should never have been there, as though it did not exist. Why is retrospective legislation being passed? It is because this Government has already broken the laws, nominating areas without an environmental impact statement. So the Government, to cover itself, is saying that this legislation will make it as though that never occurred. As there is now no need for an environmental impact statement I wonder whether the honourable member for Parramatta will again suggest a monorail around Ayers Rock, Uluru. There is no need for an environmental impact statement now so anything can occur. It will be open slather.

What effect is all this having on the economy? Mining exploration in Australia has dropped by 38 per cent. There is an undermining of confidence in investment in future developments. This sort of retrospective legislation together with the fact that there is no confidence in any compensation provisions has the mining industry in turmoil. We ought not forget and the Government ought not forget that 40 per cent of this nation's foreign earnings are from the mining industry. What will happen to our foreign debts once this legislation goes through? It will be the last nail in the coffin as regards the mining industry's confidence to continue exploring in this country.

Let me get back to what this Government is all about. For political votes it will do anything. Yesterday the Government defeated my private member's Bill. My private member's Bill purely and simply gave the right to a private owner of land to be informed when his land was put on either the interim list or the register to go on the National Estate. It is pure courtesy to let the owner know that his land is up for entry on the Register. This Government knocked it back.

Part of the argument the Minister put up was that it did not interfere with usage of the land. He said, `Give me examples'. Then he walked out of the chamber. Senator Puplick got up and said, `I will give you an example. My own property has been changed. I cannot paint it the colours I want. The local government has said that it must be painted in heritage colours'. When I spoke I also gave instances of local governments having said, `If your place is on the interim list of the National Estate we will not allow you to subdivide your property'. Yet the Minister said that it made no difference, that there were no regulations on the use of property. He asked us to give him examples but he then walked off and would not listen to them. But he did worse. He read from a letter by a representative of the local government of the City of Fremantle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the town planner there? John Dawkins's brother?

—I will come to that. I had sent my Bill to all local governments, saying, `I would like your support. This Bill gives individuals the right to know that their private property is going on the National Estate and I cannot see how the Government could knock it back. Would you give me support?' I have had support from hundreds of local governments. I have had letters from them. Only one letter I received-that from the City of Fremantle-did not give me support. Senator Richardson read from that letter in the chamber. I thought to myself, `Why is it that just one local government, only one, would not support my Bill?' Let me explain why. The Director of Planning and Development of the Fremantle City Council is a Mr Jeremy Dawkins, brother of a Labor Minister in the other place.
—He owes him a favour or two. He got a great deal of money out of him for the America's Cup.

—Not only that. Jeremy Dawkins of the Fremantle City Council not only is the Director of Planning and Development but also, just a couple of months ago, he was appointed by Senator Richardson to the Heritage Commission of the National Estate. Is it any wonder that I got a letter opposing the right of an individual to know that his property is to go on the National Estate from Jeremy Dawkins? It was not signed by Jeremy Dawkins. It was signed by a Mr Pearce. But Jeremy Dawkins is the one who pulls the strings-Jeremy Dawkins, the brother of John Dawkins, a Labor Minister in the other place. Senator Richardson gets up here and uses that sort of rubbish as evidence against a Bill which merely provides that if a person's private property is to go on the National Estate the owner should be told. That is all I ask-to let the owner know that his property is to go on the National Estate; do not sneak it on without telling him and say that he has been told because it has been advertised in the public notices in the newspaper. Not everyone reads the public notices in the newspaper. There are thousands of people in my State whose properties have gone on the National Estate without their knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is a travesty of the rights of every individual in this country. As I have said, if the people had had time to understand what this Bill was about, we would have seen demonstrations far outnumbering those against the ID card. This is the worst piece of legislation I have ever seen brought before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before us is the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. As Senator Walters has just observed, it must be, if not the worst, certainly one of the worst pieces of legislation ever to come before the Parliament. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), who is, as usual, not present for debate on his own legislation, ought to be ashamed to have put such a Bill before us. It is important to understand what this Bill is about and what it is not about. It is not about environmental policy as such. It is about the grubby politics of the New South Wales Labor Party. It is about administrative processes. It is about legislating retrospectively to rule out any possibility of legal challenge by the Queensland Government of the actions taken to this time by Senator Richardson in the name of the Commonwealth Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, as Senator Collins, who spoke somewhat earlier this morning, quite rightly pointed out, it would be possible for the Queensland Government to challenge the validity of this legislation itself before the High Court of Australia. That is not deniable. That is not in dispute. What we on this side of the chamber are saying-this also is indisputable-is that this Bill is directed to ruling out, among other things, challenge by the Queensland Government to the actions already taken by this Minister and this Government under the legislation as it currently stands prior to what I have no doubt will be, with the assistance of the Australian Democrats, the passage of this Bill.

The Bill is also about removing the Commonwealth from the need to comply with the provisions of its own Environment Protection (Impact Proposals) Act passed as long ago as 1974. It is not, of course, merely about removing the Commonwealth from the need to comply with the provisions of that Act-provisions which fall upon every other subject and entity in this country, insofar as the need to bring down environmental impact statements is concerned-before proceeding to further actions under the environmental head of power; it is also designed to remove that obligation from the Commonwealth retrospectively. Again, of course, that has to do with the fact that the current Minister's actions in regard to the North Queensland tropical rainforest matter have not complied with the provisions of that Act.

The Bill also is about setting up and giving very considerable powers to a new corps of what I can only call environmental terrorists-Richardson's greenshirts, as they have been quite appropriately called by Senator Puplick in opening the debate for our side-the so-called inspectorate provided for under this Bill, and I will come to that in a moment.

Let us be quite clear what the Bill is about. First and foremost it is about fixing up the mess Senator Richardson himself has created. If one takes it in that context and in the context, therefore, of the original proposals introduced into this place last year by the Minister to list a large area of northern Queensland under the World Heritage provisions, one sees that that proposal had nothing to do with Senator Richardson's or this Government's concern for the preservation of that piece of our environment. It had to do with a tidy bit of forward planning by the New South Wales Labor Party for the election it knew it would have to call within the following six months and which, indeed, will come to its denouement tomorrow, as it happens. That proposal in relation to the north Queensland tropical rainforest was part of the game plan to get on side the greenie vote-not in Queensland, but in New South Wales-in preparation for that forthcoming election. There is much that could be said on that topic because, of course, since that time we have had the interesting revelations about the activities of certain members of the New South Wales Labor Party in this area and their, shall I say, careless handling of the funds provided to them by a woodchipping company in Southern New South Wales, and other matters of that kind which I do not propose to take further time to go into today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bob Carr would not be too popular.

—As Senator Messner quite rightly interposed, Mr Carr would not be too popular. I simply want to make the point in this context that the present proposal, which stems from the proposal late last year on the north Queensland tropical rainforest, is a purely political initiative. It has nothing to do with environmental policy as such.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the retrospectivity aspects of the legislation. First of all, I turn to clauses 10 and 11 of the Bill. Interestingly, for those people who may not be familiar with the kind of language which this Government employs, clause 10 is headed `Proclamation never in force' and clause 11 is headed `Certain statutory rules of no effect'. Clause 10 reads:
The proclamation made on 19 January 1988-
that is, less than two months ago-
pursuant to subsection 6 (3) of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 shall be taken never to have come into force.
Clause 11 reads:
Statutory rules 1988 No. 2 shall be taken never to have had effect.

Of course, what both those clauses of the Bill are directed to doing is removing from the ambit of the High Court case which the Queensland Government has had in preparing this proclamation and those statutory rules so that the invalidity of those rules can no longer be pleaded. As the Minister said in his second reading speech on the Bill, it is proposed that, having passed this legislation, the Government will then make a new proclamation and new rules identical in form to their predecessors now to be rendered by this Bill as never having come into force. It will then proceed without any possibility of threat from the fact that the original proclamation and rules were open to legal doubt. But note the retrospectivity of the action.

The other element of the Bill which incorporates a retrospective element of a major kind is, of course, related to clauses 8 and 9 in part III of the Bill, which is headed `Amendment of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974'. Clause 9 seeks to alter the principal Act by including the following new section:
Nothing in this Act applies-
that is, in the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, after this legislation comes into force-
in relation to:
(a) the doing of any thing under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 or regulations under that Act; or

(b) the submission by the Commonwealth under Article 11 of the Convention, within the meaning of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, of property to the World Heritage Committee as suitable for inclusion in the World Heritage List . . .

That provision would mean that henceforward the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 would no longer apply to submissions by the Commonwealth for World Heritage listing or any of the other actions related thereto which the Act lays upon the Minister to perform. But the following section, proposed new section 4a (2), reads:
This section has effect as if it had commenced on the commencement of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.

That is over four years ago. That, again, is a provision clearly designed to destroy one of the bases upon which the Queensland Government would obviously have been proposing to proceed before the High Court in its argumentation-that in putting forward his proposals for dealing with the north Queensland tropical rainforest area, the Minister has not proceeded in accordance with the Commonwealth's own legislation.

Let me come to another area of the Bill which has been very properly remarked upon at some length by other speakers in this debate. I think it is one of the most extraordinary provisions to be put forward by a Minister of the Crown. It relates to the setting up of the inspectorate, Richardson's greenshirts. Clause 7 of the Bill provides, among other things, for the setting up of such a body and under the heading of `Entry and search etc.'-this is by way of providing for amendment of the initial Act-proposed new section 17a (1) of the Bill provides:
The Minister may, in writing, appoint a person to be an inspector for the purposes of this Act.
(2) An inspector may, for an eligible purpose-
that is a term which is subsequently defined-
(a) enter and search an eligible place;
(b) take photographs and record occurrences in an eligible place; and
(c) inspect, examine and take photographs and measurements of an eligible thing.
An `eligible thing' also is a term subsequently defined. For the purpose of exercising those very wide-ranging powers, the Bill provides:
. . . an inspector may stop, detain, enter and search any vehicle.
(4) An inspector shall not enter an eligible place . . . or a vehicle . . . unless:
(a) the consent of the person in charge of the eligible place or the vehicle has been obtained-
that is all right, or-
(b) pursuant to a warrant issued under subsection (5); or-
I will come back to that-
(c) the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the inspector believes on reasonable grounds-
`The inspector believes'-nobody else has any right to have any view about the matter. The inspector believes, says he believes, or is prepared to say that he believes-
that it is necessary to enter . . .
(ii) the entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant . . .
The proposed new subsection states:
`eligible place' means any land, building or structure . . . but does not include a dwelling house;
The next amendment from the Government to the legislation will be to include a dwelling house. The Bill goes on to define `eligible purpose' as:
(b) obtaining information that may be relevant-
that is, again, in the judgment or the belief, or what is said to be the belief, of the inspector-
to the making of a Proclamation, or a regulation, under this Act;
`eligible thing'-this is a term which I said I would come back to-is defined in the Act as follows:
`eligible thing' means any thing prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of this definition.

One could hardly have more extensive, far reaching and sweeping powers than that. I also think it is important to link those paragraphs of the Bill about the inspectorate with the passages about confidentiality to which Senator Walters, who spoke before me, also referred. Proposed new section 17c (1) of the Bill states:
Subject to this section, a person:
(a) who is or has been an inspector; and
(b) who has, in exercising powers under this Act, acquired any information, or document, relating to the affairs of another person;
That person shall not divulge that information. There is a penalty for breach of that provision. It goes on to say:
Nothing in subsection (1) prohibits an inspector from communicating any information, or producing any document, to the Minister, the Secretary to the Department . . .

These days he is just as likely as not to be a political creature of the Minister. The inspector is also prohibited from communicating information to other persons specified in the Bill. Without mincing words, this Bill is about setting up a bunch of people politically appointed by the Minister who will, at the Minister's request, if necessary, undertake or exercise their extraordinary wide-ranging powers to enter, search, and take photographs of eligible things as defined by regulations made by the Minister and who, having done that, can communicate all that information to the Minister. If that is not a police state, I would like to know what is.

I note also just in passing-this is on another element of the Bill-the section dealing with compensation. It has been argued by the Minister in his second reading speech and I think by one or two of the rather small number of speakers on the Government side of the chamber-I think it is probably difficult to find speakers on that side of the chamber who are prepared to come in and support this stuff-that these provisions relating to compensation represent an improvement upon the procedures under the principal Act. There is some justification for that view. I accept that. However, what we should note is that these compensation provisions apply only where a property is actually acquired by the Commonwealth. There is no provision in this Bill or the principal Act for compensation where management of a property is affected-at the discretion of the Commonwealth, of course; the discretion of the Minister-but where acquisition does not ultimately occur, as Senator Walters said when she was referring to the inquiry provisions. An inquiry can go on for five years. There is nothing in this Bill to prevent an inquiry going on interminably. If the Minister wants it to go on a bit longer, he can give another reference or alter the reference somewhat to maintain the inquiry in being. There is no hindrance on his capacity to do that, none at all. Just think of the capacities for political blackmail-I do not apologise for using that phrase-which those sorts of powers give to this Minister. Just think of the way in which this particular Minister might be prepared to use them.

In the time that remains to me I will say a few more general things about the matters and topics to which the Bill itself relates; namely, environmental policy. I believe that I am as much concerned with the need to preserve the Australian environment as I believe are most other sensible Australians. After all, it is our country. It is not some mere play thing of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation or, for that matter, of various so-called concerned foreigners such as Professor David Bellamy, or other notables of that kind.

I find it extremely disturbing that we have all these debates in Australia today-I think it might be more accurate to describe them as emotional uproars-proceeding about issues such as uranium mining, or mining generally within the confines of areas delineated as national parks; or selective logging of small numbers of mature trees in afforested areas, including, but not exclusively, rainforests; or the preservation of birds, such as galahs; or animals such as kangaroos, whose presence, I might say, in virtually plague numbers, wreak havoc with the livelihoods of many hard-working Australian farmers. I am perfectly well aware that one of the more respectable arguments of the environmentalist lobby is that the very presence of unspoiled wilderness itself constitutes a powerful drawcard for one of our fast-growing industries-tourism. I think that argument is the more powerful since, after all, we are not overburdened with fast-growing industries in Australia today, if we leave aside the Public Service which can hardly be described as an industry. In any case, I think it is something of a contradiction in terms.

One of Australia's greatest attractions on the worldwide scene is the opportunity which it still offers to people from more physically crowded environments to get away from it all. There is no argument about that and I am quite sure that there would not be any dispute about that in this chamber. It is the prospect of savouring the splendour, albeit the often harsh splendour, of the Australian emptiness that can itself provide a powerful inducement for people to come to Australia as tourists. That is true whether we are speaking of tourism in the context of tourism, or whether we are speaking of tourism in the context of attracting appropriate immigrants to add to our community.

As I have said, there cannot be any argument that wilderness or, for that matter, our more engaging forms of wildlife-and we have many of them-represent in themselves tourist attractions. It is one thing to say that the unique natural beauty of Cape Tribulation, for example, must therefore be preserved on that account, among others; in other words, that regard for the environment and for our economic future is not in conflict in such a case. It is quite a different thing to move from that position to the kinds of remotely imposed diktats which assert that thousands of square miles of country, in some cases not even neighbouring country, not remotely comparable in environmental quality with the uniqueness of Cape Tribulation, should be forever locked away in the public domain because Senator Richardson chooses to do so for some short term political gain, as he perhaps wrongly, I think, judges it.

I believe that that example illustrates a more general point. I do not assert that people on the spot always know best, but to me there is something deeply disturbing in the manner in which increasingly decisions about environmental matters are being taken in and imposed from Canberra. What I regretfully have to describe as the High Court's prostitution of the external affairs power of the Constitution, which has largely been responsible for giving rise to that situation, is now leading to a most serious situation. The judicial politics involved have led to a situation, not only in this area of policy, where the most far-reaching decisions are being taken by Ministers and by their advisers who have no personal affiliations with the areas to which those decisions relate or to the people in those areas over whose fates and whose livelihoods they are so prejudicially presiding. I firmly believe that, in due course, there will be a need for some constitutional review of the consequences to which the current abuse of the external affairs power of the Constitution is now leading in these and other respects. But I leave that aside for the moment.

In conclusion, I want to make the point that the choice ought not to be one between concerns to promote economic growth on the one hand and environmental concerns on the other; the choice is rather between the various ends to which economic growth, which fundamentally means greater capacity to do what we wish to do, can be directed. If that proposition were accepted it follows that a country which does not succeed in achieving economic growth for its citizens and the increase in living standards which goes with that, is unlikely to be able for long to preserve its environmental treasures. We do not find very much debate proceeding in Brazil about logging the timber to be found in the forests of that country. About the only people pursuing that matter are to be found in various United Nations agencies or in the comfort of armchairs in other countries whose standards of living are much higher than that of Brazil.

But, more generally, the preservation of some aspects of the environment has a cost-either an actual cost or a potential cost. I simply do not know, for example, whether the seabed now contained within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park might cover large deposits of oil or natural gas because exploration and drilling there have been forbidden on the grounds that it might result in damage to the park. For that reason, presumably we shall never know what will be the cost to future generations of Australians of removing that huge area from our potential petroleum resource base. I am not arguing that, even if we did know that a large oil pool was present there, we should develop it. I am simply saying that we should know. No individual would set about making a decision in his personal life without trying to acquire all the facts relevant to that decision. Increasingly, what Australians are doing, and what governments are doing, ostensibly on their behalf, is locking away large parts of the country and removing, forever presumably, our capacity to find out what it is we are losing by doing so. That process, which has now resulted in about 23 per cent of the Australian landmass largely being denied to mineral exploration, for example, is simply a process which cannot go on forever and which must lead increasingly not merely to grave questions about the desirability of that policy but also to grave questions about the whole of our approach to the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. Mr President, I understand that you wish to make a statement in five minutes time which allows me, therefore, five minutes to make a few comments and, when I see your nod, I will sit down. It gives me an opportunity to do what I particularly wanted to do and, that is, move an amendment that came out of Question Time yesterday in which it was confirmed by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) that an interdepartmental committee had been set out by this Government to look at the question of land use-in other words, to look at the question of the relationship of environmental aspects with primary industry, tourism, mining and perhaps some other area. Unfortunately, as yet, we do not have the terms of reference of that interdepartmental committee so we are not entirely sure of the breadth of its inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: But we, on this side of the Senate, certainly commend our colleague Senator Watson for bringing this to our attention through his questioning of the Minister. It indicates to us that in-depth consideration is being given by the Government to these various aspects and they may well substantially affect the contents of this Bill. As we know, this Bill deals with the question of compensation and that could well be affected by what this committee comes up with after its investigation. The Bill also deals with one other aspect which we on this side of the chamber oppose, and that is the removal from the Government of the obligation to conduct environmental impact studies in relation to World Heritage management plans and the like. There may well be information that comes forth from this interdepartmental committee that is relevant to that consideration.

Adding all this up, particularly bearing in mind that we are somewhat in the dark, and taking into account the Minister's comments in his answer to a question yesterday that he expects this inquiry to report towards the end of April, we seek, and I quote from the amendment that has been circulated:
That consideration of this Bill be deferred pending the report of the inter-departmental committee which is currently looking at land use.

We on this side of the chamber have made clear our strong support for conservation and I certainly reiterate my support for the World Heritage conservation regime. As I have only one minute left I refer honourable senators to the speech I made in 1983 when I set down our position in great depth. It remains sound. We support the Convention for the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Our belief is that it is the responsibility of all Australians to protect these marvellous assets, cultural and natural, not only for the Australians living today but also for future generations. Having said that, we find shortcomings and failures in this Bill. I have mentioned the fact that the Government is removing from itself the obligation to conduct environmental impact studies. We also see the Bill as unnecessary in that the Lemonthyme High Court case has covered one matter that relates to protecting the environment pending placing on the list. The Bill is not necessary; it is not urgent in any event and therefore it would be in the best interests of the whole of the Senate to have it deferred until we get the report of the interdepartmental committee which we expect by the end of April. Therefore I move:
Leave out all the words after `That', insert: `consideration of this Bill be deferred pending the report of the inter-departmental committee which is currently looking at land use'.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
