—My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. I ask: In the light of the Federal Government's responsibility to maintain accurate and honest electoral rolls, what credence can be given to Senator Bishop's claim that the Castlereagh by-election was subject to massive electoral fraud?
—This is not a Federal affair.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume just said that this is not a Federal affair, although I know he did not say it loudly. Of course, it is. The rolls and certified lists are provided by the Australian Electoral Commission, as happened in 1980 in this case. So there is a substantial Federal interest in this matter. I might also say that there is a broader interest in this matter because, if what is alleged did occur on this occasion, people would rightly ask whether it has occurred in Federal elections.

ANSWER.PARA: According to this series of allegations, Mr Begg is supposed to have derived his data from a regional newspaper office. We have checked with the current Divisional Returning Officer in the Castlereagh region, and with the past one. There are no regional newspaper offices based in that electorate. The nearest one is in Dubbo. Indeed, there is no one newspaper that covers the whole of the electorate. There is a whole series of newspapers. So the first element of the claim tends to be a little weakened. There is no evidence to support an allegation about anyone going to a regional newspaper office because one does not exist in the area.

The second thing that would worry me is simply that the maths do not add up. We have checked certain figures. The average number of deaths of electors per month is one per thousand. There were at the time of this by-election 21,000 to 22,000 electors in Castlereagh-not 28,828 or whatever the Sydney Morning Herald quoted this morning. I am not sure whether or not that figure came from Senator Bishop, but it was in the Sydney Morning Herald. There were slightly below 22,000 electors in the electorate. This means that to accumulate the necessary 400 names would take in the order of 1 1/2 years. That, of course, is provided that the name of every person who died appeared in an obituary. We all know that that is not particularly likely. So the best projection one can make is that in the order of two years would be required in this electorate to accumulate 400 names.

Now let me get to the crucial point, because this apparently has not been understood. In the period we are talking about-and we have checked the record-there were no hitches in the dispatch by the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages to the Divisional Returning Officer for Gwydir. That is, every month the Divisional Returning Officer for Gwydir received from the Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages a list of the deaths that had occurred in that electorate. In this electorate we were fortunate at the time to have a very old-fashioned, a very diligent and a very conscientious Divisional Returning Officer. Month by month, that Divisional Returning Officer adjusted the roll in cases of death.

There are a few other factors that we should take into account. In an electorate such as Castlereagh, if these allegations were to have foundation, we would be dealing with a hamlet electorate. I think most people would know what I am referring to. In other words, seven polling booths in the Castlereagh electorate were used by more than 1,000 voters; 45 booths were used by fewer than 1,000 voters. We have also to remember that people voted within subdivisions at the time-a system that some Liberals make a big point of wanting to return to. It is fairly inconceivable to me that, in a small country electorate with small booths, bodgie votes could be lodged. Nearly all the officials are locals. They know whether Mrs Smith or Mr Jones has passed away in the last couple of years. Again, there is not much evidence to support the allegations in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the absentee vote?

—I will get to that point later if the honourable senator likes. I was not going to raise it, but I will come to it. At the very best, at any one time, because of the month's lag between a person dying and the notification, 20 or 30 individuals on that roll could have been deceased. We can also compare the census figures at the time for the number of people who should have been on the roll and the number who were on the roll to see whether the rolls were padded. We have done that. In fact, in the Castlereagh electorate that relationship was on the low side, not the high side.

ANSWER.PARA: I come back to the question of Federal elections just to reassure people that these sorts of things are most unlikely to occur. After the last Federal election the Electoral Commission checked every recent death and checked whether any of the deceased-the ultimate absentee vote-were registered as having voted in that election. As I understand it, 144 electorates showed a totally clean slate. I think that in three other electorates there was one case each, and by investigation it was found essentially that a postal voting form had arrived, having been properly applied for, and that the family had voted and sent it off, may be on the basis that they did not want follow-up letters or that they knew grandmother or grandfather wanted to vote Liberal or Labor-basically a breach of the Act but not one that we would say was earth shattering.

Finally, in one Federal electorate there were six to eight cases of people who had died apparently voting. It was the electorate of Capricornia, and this has been mentioned in the newspapers. Our investigations so far-they are not conclusive-indicate that no political party was attached to that matter but that an eccentric was responsible for it. There is a great protection against anyone in the electorate who would like to get the dead to vote. There is a Court of Disputed Returns. That means that, in a State or Federal election, if anyone were foolish enough to discover the 20, 30 or 40 people whose names were still on the roll, the other 500 or 600 names having been cleansed from it, and vote in their names, that would show up after the election and the Electoral Commission could lodge its own protest and have that election turned over. So it is not particularly likely to happen. I can recall only one instance of the cemetery vote in my time in politics. That was in a Liberal Party pre-selection in 1975-76 in Victoria, where pre-selection had to be taken from a particular individual because half of Brighton's cemetery was found to have voted. That was the last major case.

I say in conclusion that these allegations have received a lot of publicity. I am not critical of Senator Bishop for raising them. If allegations of impropriety are there, they should be raised. One could be a little dubious about the timing-the fact that it was the Thursday before the forthcoming election-but, leaving that aside, I am not critical of her for raising them. But I wonder what has happened to empiricism. I wonder why Senator Bishop did not apply some of the tests I have applied today before those allegations were produced. It would have meant a more balanced and a slightly less politically opportunistic approach. I repeat that, whilst I cannot say conclusively that the allegations made by Senator Bishop in relation to the Castlereagh by-election are not true, the general weight of evidence suggests that the so-called cemetery vote in those circumstances is a most unlikely occurrence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs, follows the answer he has just given. I seek a little more information on the matters that he gave us a few moments ago. I ask: Is the Minister in a position to confirm whether or not the Mr Begg who was referred to by Senator Bishop in her speech was at the relevant times employed by the Australian Labor Party or by a Minister in the capacity described? I further ask: Has any attempt been made to contact Mr Begg to investigate the allegations which have been made, and which are purported to have been made by Mr Begg himself, according to the tape recording? Has he been interviewed? Having already heard about the sorts of empirical studies that have been undertaken since the honourable senator made her speech yesterday, I ask: What action is being taken to investigate the allegations allegedly made by Mr Begg about Mr Begg, and who is undertaking the investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just checked one detail with a colleague. I understand that at the time the alleged offence occurred, Mr Begg was an employee of Mr Hallam, who was a New South Wales State Minister. At a different time-probably I think earlier-he would have been in the employ of Mr Wran. As to whether I have made any attempt to contact Mr Begg--
—I did not mean you personally.

—No, I have not. It is one of those awkward areas, if you like, of jurisdiction. If an offence occurred, it is essentially a State offence. However, there is a Federal interest in the matter because we supply rolls. If an offence occurred, the relevant question could be put to us as to why we supplied defective rolls. I very much contest that we did supply defective rolls at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not made any attempt to contact Mr Begg. I understand that a lot of people have but have not got a big response so far. I do not know Mr Begg personally. I have never met Mr Begg. I assume if I or the Australian Electoral Commission rang him today we probably would not get a response. Let me turn to the allegations. If it can be proved that the tape is genuine, that Mr Begg made those statements, there is a necessity for an inquiry somewhere. I would have thought that in the first instance it would be New South Wales-based. If that does not transpire in any particular way, I will look to see what Federal inquiries can be made so that this matter can be put, if you like, to rest forever.

While I am on my feet, I might just answer an interjection that was made by Senator Michael Baume. He said, `Look, they could have not voted in the subdivisions; they could have all voted absentee'. First of all, we would need all of the names on the roll, and I am saying that they cannot be there. But even if they were, there would need to be signatures and those signatures are usually compared with the enrolment card, a la the first Nunawading one, in which there was a dispute because of a drawn vote and some names were excluded because the signatures did not correspond. So, in fact, there is another safeguard in terms of absentee votes. I can see that Senator Baume has given this matter a lot of thought. I am sorry that his latest ingenious solution just does not stand up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. For the purpose of clarification, I ask the Minister whether he means, when he says `I have made no attempt to contact Mr Begg', that neither he nor the Commonwealth electoral authorities have made any attempt? Am I correct in taking his answer to mean that he is suggesting that the initial obligation to make an inquiry into this matter rests with State authorities, although there may be a residual duty on the Commonwealth? I understood his answer to be that, but I would just like it to be clarified.

—I confirm that I have not attempted to do so and, to the best of my knowledge, having spoken to the Chief Electoral Commissioner, Dr Hughes, he has not attempted to do so yet. He may well do so; and if he does, he does not have to inform me that he is in fact doing it. I do confirm that I think because it involves the State electoral Act, if there were any breaches it rests with New South Wales first of all, although there is, as I have explained before, a Federal interest because we have joint rolls. We are the agents responsible for cleansing those rolls. Again I state that I think we have done a fairly good job of doing that in that particular electorate.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Minister's recent visit to China for the second meeting of the Australia-China Joint Ministerial Economic Commission (JMEC). Can the Minister advise on the prospects for Australia's trade and investment in China and any new opportunities which are likely to occur in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I attended the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission held in Beijing on 8 March.
—Is that near Peking?

—Yes, it is very close, Senator. One eats Peking duck in Beijing, if that is what the honourable senator is trying to suggest-which would probably be close to his mind. I was accompanied by the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy.
—You are a sophisticated lot.

—Well, Senator Aulich is. I was also accompanied by senior officials from major economic policy departments and Austrade. At the time of our visit there was also a parliamentary delegation to China which, in a geographical sense, covered a much wider area than we did in connection with the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The JMEC was established by the Government to provide a ministerial-level forum to review and guide the development of Australia-China commercial relations. I remind the Senate that Australia's exports to China more than tripled from $A468m in 1983, the year this Government took office, to $A1,587m in 1986. I think the main achievement at last week's meeting was the conclusion of an arrangement under which Australia will provide, over the next three years, up to $200m in concessional finance for the supply of Australian goods and services for development projects in China. This arrangement should produce a substantial increase in exports of equipment and services to China, and a greater presence by Australian firms in the Chinese marketplace, which in itself is a very good thing.

During the course of the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission we reviewed the work of several industry-based initiatives which operate under the mechanism of the JMEC in relation to wool, iron and steel, non-ferrous metals, transport, telecommunications and coal, including such matters as China's major investment in the Mount Channar iron ore mine and the opening of a large wool warehouse in Nanjing, which will take place this week. We also agreed to further cooperation in relation to machinery and electrical equipment. That cooperation is designed to encourage an additional penetration of the Australian market by Chinese imports in that area, amongst other things. We agreed on further collaboration in science and technology to help raise trade, investment and exchange in these areas.

We also discussed with Chinese Ministers the possibility of commercial cooperation in aspects of the automotive industry and invited a survey mission from China to visit Australia later this year in connection with that. I suppose, finally and importantly, Mr Duffy and I obtained assurances from the Minister for Metallurgical Industry, Mr Qi Yuanjing, that Australia's share of China's imports of iron ore would be maintained at its current level of 70 per cent until the turn of the century. This, of course, will be of great value to Australia, particularly at a time when the prospects for exports of iron ore have not been particularly bright.

I conclude by saying that there are recognised difficulties for Australian companies doing business in China. I think the Joint Ministerial Economic Commission was able to draw the attention of the Chinese side to these problems. For example, there will be a more diligent pursuit of the negotiation of a double taxation agreement as a result of the meeting and other things. I think it is a helpful forum. Of course, in the year ahead we will be better able to assess the results of that meeting than we can now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. By way of preamble, I point out that my question arises at this time because of the proposal for a petrochemical plant in Kwinana in Western Australia, but that the question has general significance in relation to a number of petrochemical proposals which have been made since the early 1970s. Is the Minister aware that ethylene dichloride (EDC) and vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) are intermediates in the manufacture of polyvinyl chloride (PVC) from ethane? Is the Minister aware that both EDC and VCM are known potent mutagens and carcinogens? Is the Minister aware of the number of petrochemical plants which are involved in the manufacture of PVC from ethane which either make and export one of these dangerous intermediate products or use one of these products as a feedstock? In view of the number of proposals in recent years, the most recent now being considered in Western Australia, to turn ethane into EDC and/or VCM, to break the process at this most hazardous stage and to export these highly dangerous intermediate products to far distant sites for completion of PVC manufacture, does the Minister consider this arrangement satisfactory? If not, will the Minister undertake an inquiry-an inquiry which was not possible under State environmental impact study type procedures-perhaps under the Federal Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, with public hearings, to lay down better ground rules for the conduct of this potentially very beneficial, but also potentially very hazardous, component of the petrochemical industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall read some sections of my answer to Senator Coulter. I confess that whilst I know the honourable senator has an abiding interest in these things, some of the chemical names leave me a little cold.

ANSWER.PARA: The first part of the question asked whether I was aware that ethylene dichloride and vinyl chloride monomer are intermediates in the manufacture of polyvinyl chloride. Polyvinyl chloride is used in the manufacture of a host of plastic products used in our community, such as water pipes, food containers, flooring and electrical insulation. Both EDC and VCM are known to be mutagenic; that is, they are chemicals which can cause damage to genetic material. Additionally, VCM is listed by the International Agency for Research into Cancer as a human carcinogen. EDC is known to cause tumours in animals but it has not been confirmed as causing cancer in humans.

I am advised that there is one plant in New South Wales that manufactures EDC and VCM as intermediates for the production of PVC on the same site, and that two PVC plants in Victoria import these intermediate chemicals. The land transport of EDC and VCM is subject to the Australian Code for the Transport of Dangerous Goods by Road and Rail, which is implemented through the relevant dangerous goods legislation of the States and Territories. The equivalent provisions for sea transport apply under the international maritime dangerous goods code.

In the light of the potential hazards of VCM and EDC it is of course most important that all proper safeguards be observed when they are transported and that the relevant codes are kept up to date and are suitably rigorous. I am unaware of deficiencies having been identified in the present regulatory requirements covering the transport of EDC and VCM. Appropriate precautions are necessary at all stages, including the manufacture, storage and handling.

The current proposal by Petrochemical Industries Co. Ltd to establish and operate an integrated petrochemical complex in Western Australia does not involve a Commonwealth decision, and therefore does not come within the ambit of the Commonwealth's Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. However, I am advised that an environmental review and management program has been prepared on this proposal in accordance with requirements under the Western Australian Environment Protection Act 1986. This document has been released for public review and the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority is currently considering the environmental aspects of the proposal. In view of the actions taken by Western Australia and other States in relation to this matter, I do not believe that any useful purpose would be served by a general inquiry at this time by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's reply referred to the transport of these very dangerous intermediate products, and I stress the intermediate nature of the products in the manufacturing process. Is the Minister aware that several years ago there was a very dangerous spill of VCM at the B. F. Goodrich Chemical Ltd plant at Altona and that in fact we have experienced the failure of the safe transport of these dangerous products in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the incident to which Senator Coulter refers. I understand that on that occasion the gas was blown away from residential areas by the wind and that no harm was caused to any individuals. However, it is obviously a dangerous business and, as I said in my original answer, any dangerous business needs to have rigorous controls. At this stage the controls would appear to be rigorous enough. It may be the case that after the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority's inquiry I can review what I have just said, but I will wait to see what that inquiry has to say.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to the apprehension of Indonesian fishing vessels off the north-west coast of Western Australia and the crew members' subsequent processing in Broome. Can the Minister confirm or deny whether at least one crew member from the Saliputa was identified as belonging to the Indonesian special defence or security forces? If the answer is in the affirmative, can the Minister indicate what significance he would attach to this fact? Have there been other incidents of this kind where members of Indonesia's armed forces have been recognised among illegal fishermen as having been trained in Australian defence establishments? Is the Government prepared to review military training as part of the defence cooperation program considering the misuse of Australian-gained expertise in countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Fiji?

—I am informed that none of the members of the crews of any of the vessels referred to has been identified as belonging to any military or security organisation. I am unaware of any occasion on which members of Indonesia's armed forces have been recognised amongst illegal fishermen apprehended in Australian waters. It follows that none has been identified as having been trained in Australia's military establishments. The issue therefore provides no grounds for a review of our defence cooperation program.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to media reports about the current level of unemployment in Australia, which is reported to be below 7.5 per cent nationally. Whilst I congratulate the Government on these figures, can the Minister inform the Senate what progress has been made in relation to youth unemployment in Australia?

—The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force statistics, which are for February of this year, have shown that Australia's current unemployment rate is 7.4 per cent, which is a full 3.5 percentage points lower than the unemployment rate at the peak of the Fraser-Howard induced 1982-83 recession.
—The Bill Kelty induced recession; is that the one you are talking about?

—We know all about the wages explosion. As Senator Button has pointed out here before, I suppose Senator Stone was the then Government's chief bureaucratic adviser on how to design a wages policy, and was presumably quite happy with Mr Fraser deciding that it was more important to clear out to the royal wedding in May 1981 than it was to do anything about having a national wages policy. We know that the outcome of that first dangerous flirtation was to allow free collective bargaining to determine wages. We know that there was an increase of 13 per cent in 1981 and 14 per cent in 1982. We have had that flirtation with Senator Stone's policy, Howard's policy and Fraser's policy and we do not want any more of it, thanks. I am surprised that even with Senator Stone's propensity to come to predetermined conclusions, and then to try to get the evidence to support the predetermined conclusions, he has not had second thoughts about whether it is such a good idea to have decentralised free collective bargaining.
—You are heading that way yourself.
—Not that way. Senator Stone says that national governments should make no attempt to coordinate wages policy.
—You need some help.
—When I need some help, Senator Stone, I certainly will not go to you for it, whether it is about what offence the Tolpuddle Martyrs were convicted of, or anything else.
—You even got that wrong.

—Oh no, I did not. Would the honourable senator like me to table the information? I think I can probably get it by the end of Question Time. I will table the documentary evidence of what the Tolpuddle Martyrs were convicted of. It was not of burning ricks; it was of taking a secret oath, as I said. Anyway, that is a personal dispute and we should not bore the rest of the Senate with it.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask the Minister to return to the question that he was asked.

—The threshold for the tolerance of boredom here should be pretty high, if practice helps. On the question of the youth unemployment rate-that is, the 15- to 19-year-old age group-it is true that this is considerably higher than the 7.4 per cent average unemployment rate. It is presently 19.2 per cent, which everyone acknowledges is too high, but that is a very marked improvement on the 23.2 per cent youth unemployment rate in February 1987, let alone the 27 per cent youth unemployment rate recorded during the depths of the Fraser-Howard 1981-82 recession.
—How much?

—It was 27 per cent for the 15- to 19-year age group during the recession of 1981-82. The youth unemployment figures are not available by States on a seasonally adjusted basis, but the available data indicates that New South Wales has seen the greatest improvement in its youth labour market during the past 12 months. It has also had the greatest improvement in the labour market generally. In New South Wales the unemployment rate for 15- to 19-year-olds seeking full time work declined by a full 7.2 percentage points in the year from February 1987 to February 1988. This was the highest of all the States.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health and relates to this Government's so-called commitment to work constructively in partnership with the non-government sector in the advancement of disability services. Is the Minister aware of the fact that the funding available to community and service groups under the Disability Services Act for capital purposes has been so severely cut that there are now many hundreds of disabled persons throughout Australia on waiting lists for placement in workshop situations. Does the Minister condone the deplorable situation in which supported employment institutions throughout Australia have not yet received their 1987-88 funding, some nine months into the financial year? Can the Minister appreciate what trauma this is creating among disabled people throughout Australia and the confusion and horror within these honourable institutions which will receive little or no funding for equipment and capital works this year while they continue to be inundated with requests to cater for more disabled people?
—That is a very interesting question. I do not have a brief on it at the moment. Therefore, I propose to put it on notice and come back to the honourable senator.

—While Senator Cook is looking at his brief on that matter, perhaps he could consider this supplementary question also. How does the Minister justify a situation where 78 centres which are successfully operating demonstration projects under the Act have received no firm future commitment on their funding, which expires in June? Will the persons living in supported homes under this scheme be tossed on to the streets? QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he has seen Mr Paddy McGuinness's column in today's Australian Financial Review in which he cites one of the gurus of supply side economics, Mr Alan Reynolds, as saying in reference to this decade:

QUESTION.PARA: In the US and the UK, the share of income taxes collected from the most affluent 5 per cent of taxpayers increased quite dramatically after higher tax rates were reduced.

Does this constitute real evidence that supply side economics is not snake oil? Does it give credence to Mr Howard's claim that massive tax cuts for the rich would pay for themselves? Do this Government's taxation policies stand in stark contrast to the Opposition's position on taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last part of the question, I do not believe one could get a contrast any more stark than that between a government that gets its arithmetic right and an opposition that cannot. That is particularly so when the error in the Opposition's arithmetic is of the magnitude of $1.5 billion. The Opposition's addition was about as credible as its policy concepts.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to the earlier part of the question, I have seen Paddy McGuinness's article; I believe he calls himself Padraic these days. I have not had a chance to check the United States data but I have some facts about the position in the United Kingdom. It is true that the proportion of total income tax paid by the highest earning 5 per cent of British taxpayers increased from 24 per cent to 27 per cent between 1979 and 1986. But before everyone gets carried away with that as being evidence, or even proof as some may suggest, that the supply side theory and the Laffer curve is soundly based, I should point out that some other more significant changes took place in that period. For example, The Economist of 23 to 29 May 1987 said:

The government likes to point out that the proportion of total income tax paid by the top 5% of earners has risen from 24% in 1979 to 27% last year. This, it claims, shows that lower marginal tax rates encourage people to work harder. Part of the explanation is that the pre-tax earnings of the higher paid have risen more rapidly.
In another part of the article it is pointed out:
. . . wage differentials have widened: the lowest 10% of male earners have had a real pay increase of only 4%; the top 10% one of 22%.

If we were able to extract the top 5 per cent from that 10 per cent we would expect the real pay increase for that group to be considerably higher than 22 per cent. In those circumstances when there has been a pre-tax redistribution of income or change in income skewed very heavily to the top end of the income scale, it should not be surprising that people at the top end of that scale paid a bit more tax than they would have before. I do not think I need to read any more quotations from Mr McGuinness's article, but I stress that that is a very important rebuttal of the United Kingdom situation, published in The Economist.

Finally, it is a pity that this silly debate about snake oil-that is, supply side theory-is still being peddled in Australia because the magic wand solutions which that theory encourages are only impediments to the proper and rational resolution of the nation's economic difficulties. I know that Mr Peacock is embarrassed by having to peddle this rubbish in speeches he has to make publicly. The sooner he can persuade John Howard to drop his commitments to the supply side voodoo, snake oil theory the better. Alternatively, if he cannot persuade Mr Howard to drop this theory, the sooner he replaces Mr Howard as Opposition Leader the better it will be for rational debate of this important issue in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: If I may refer to some other evidence-again, I cited this the other day-advertised job vacancies in New South Wales as a proportion of the work force are vastly higher than in any other State, as is the increase in the amount of overtime worked during 1987. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. —In view of the highly welcome news of the stay of execution for the so-called Sharpeville six, will the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade outline the efforts of the Australian Government and particularly the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, in helping to bring about this successful result? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the Australian Government will continue to fight for the Sharpeville six to be dealt with honestly and to ensure the stay of execution becomes permanent in the form of an eventual reprieve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very welcome news that a stay of execution has been granted by the Pretoria Supreme Court-not the Government, the court-for the Sharpeville six to 18 April, based on new evidence concerning a key witness who claims that evidence he gave implicating at least some of the six was obtained under duress. This decision does not itself constitute the granting of a retrial but it does allow time for lawyers for the defence to prepare an application to the court for a retrial. In considering the application the court will determine whether or not there was a reasonable possibility that given all the evidence a new trial could produce a different result. I emphasise that the stay of execution was a decision of the court and one granted purely on legal grounds. It does not represent a commutation in any way of the death penalty by the South African President, which the Australian Government and other Western governments have sought. Nevertheless, we obviously welcome the opportunity which may now be available to have the case reopened, having in mind that the rejection of their appeal against sentence was not based on any conclusive finding that there was a direct causal connection between the conduct of the accused and the death of the victim but rather on the grounds that there was an alleged common purpose between the unidentified actual murderers and the six.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government's position remains as has been articulated on numerous occasions publicly and with a great deal of vigour by Mr Hayden and in direct communications he has made with representatives of the South African Government. Our position is that the execution of the Sharpeville six would exacerbate an already volatile political climate caused by the continuing denial of political freedoms to the vast majority of South Africa's people. We will continue to urge the South African authorities to demonstrate their readiness to reduce tensions and confrontation by commuting the death sentence in this case.

Finally, we hope in this respect that we will have rather more support from the Opposition in making those representations than has been evident in the contributions to debate on this matter from Mr Spender, the Liberal spokesman on foreign affairs matters, and also from Opposition members such as Senator Calvert who spoke on the adjournment last night. They seemed to salve their consciences by making the odd cautionary noise to South African ambassadors at cocktail parties or over dinners. It is tremendously important that we as a nation and as a Parliament express a unanimity of purpose and a unanimity of moral vision when confronted with the inequity and the outrages perpetrated by that regime. Temporising of the kind we are hearing now, that we heard over and over again from people on the other side of this place; temporising of the kind we heard in a disgraceful fashion from Mr Spender, the purported spokesman on foreign affairs matters, does not help in any way to get justice into that society which manifestly lacks it at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRESIDENT OF THE LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications both in that capacity and in his capacity today of Minister representing the Minister for Justice and the Attorney-General, Senator Tate's not being present. Has the Minister seen the reported comments of the National President of the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr John Elliott, in an address in London this week in which he said that what Australia needs, amongst other things, is strong leadership and limited democracy, and that ethnic Australians should not seek to maintain individual cultural differences. As it appears that these statements were made off the cuff, and maybe represent the inner thoughts of E1 Supremo of the Liberal Party, will the Minister concede that strong leadership and limited democracy are but a short step from dictatorship? What implications might such statements have for institutions such as the Special Broadcasting Service, in the unlikely event that the Opposition ever attains government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports of Mr Elliott's speech in a number of newspapers, including the Australian Financial Review of Thursday this week. Copies of the speech itself do not seem to be readily available, probably because Mr Elliott was prudent enough not to give wider release to his manifestly bizarre view of the world expressed in that speech, and maybe also because the odd crate of his best known product was part of the inspiration for its delivery. The speech reportedly describes Mr Elliott as prescribing, as a remedy to return Australia to greatness, strong leadership, singular purpose and limited democracy, as Senator Gietzelt has said. Mr Elliott went on to say that what Australia does not need are `special interest groups, like the Aborigines, who want handouts from the Government'. Not content with this, Mr Elliott went on to wax lyrical about pro-assimilation and his view that, if a person comes to live in Australia that person should `seek to become a member of the all-Australian team and not maintain individual cultural differences'.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite simply, these statements not only are disconcerting in themselves but also give quite an alarming insight into the kind of society a future Liberal government would be under pressure to turn Australia into and the policies that such a government would certainly pursue if Mr Elliott were to achieve his well-known ambition to lead the Parliamentary Liberal Party. When he talks about limited democracy, what on earth does he mean? How limited a democracy does he mean? I suppose we can give him the benefit of the doubt and assume that he would not immediately try to turn Australia into the kind of one-man authoritarian band that is symptomatic of his corporations.

I do not know how far he would be prepared to go in terms of limiting the right to protest, the freedom of the Press or the rights of trade unionists, but certainly from the rest of the tenor of his speech, as reported, it would have an awful lot to do with limiting the democratic role and rights of particular minority interest groups in this country, including the Aboriginal people who, as reported, Mr Elliott does not seem to think have any role in this society. No doubt his initial limitation of democracy would be to return to the pre-1962 period and take away the right to vote from Australia's indigenous people. If this speech is any guide, no doubt he would also be attracted to the scrapping of land rights laws, which is, of course, already very much part of the New South Wales Greiner Opposition view of the world.

From the point of view of my portfolio, the most alarming single thing about the Elliott speech is the total hostility and contempt it demonstrates towards the concept of multiculturalism. In the Elliott view of the world, the role and responsibility of ethnic communities in this country would be to applaud and no doubt barrack something like, `Good on you digger' as they watched the scrapping of the Special Broadcasting Service, the Ethnic Affairs Commission, foreign language education and any other institution or organisation that had anything other than a wholesome Caucasian flavour. As reported, it was a disgraceful speech. The content of it deserves much wider circulation because it does give a very great insight into what the Liberal Party and its leading spokesmen are all about, and what in particular a Greiner government in New South Wales would be all about, if they could persuade the Australian electorate into voting for Mr Elliott's party.

The answer read as follows-
The Senate may be interested to know that since 1980 the Commonwealth has been undertaking widespread search operations in the Warnbro area to locate and dispose of unexploded ordnance.

Taking account of the substantial land development occurring in the Warnbro area, the Commonwealth and Western Australian governments agreed in March 1986 on new arrangements for completing the search operations at Warnbro. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Hamer proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The cost to every Australian of inefficiencies, restrictive work practices and lack of competition on the Australian waterfront highlighted by the continuing chaos on the Sydney docks.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is a very appropriate one to be debated in this Senate because it is a matter which has far-reaching consequences for Australia as a whole; not just for New South Wales. Everyone knows that the critically weak element in our shipping operations is the wharfside. Everyone knows that waterside work practices and productivity have been appalling, but there is an additional problem. Our ports are vulnerable to being picked off by other trade unions upstream in the transport sequence. For example, two strikes in Queensland mines this year have already caused serious and expensive transport delays. Between 21 January and 9 February five ships were delayed at Hay Point and Dalrymple Bay, with a total loss of 38 ship days, because of a mining strike. Between 12 January and 5 February two ships were delayed in Gladstone, with a total loss of 33 days, again as a result of a mining strike.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of these sorts of strikes on our credibility as a reliable exporter is devastating. We are exporting into a highly competitive market. If we get the reputation, as I fear we have, of being an unreliable supplier, people will look for alternatives. The world does not owe us a living. If we do not earn it, we will not get it-a fact which seems to have escaped the present Government.

We have 41 major public ports. We have a dozen privately operated commercial ports and numerous smaller ports. The efficient handling of goods in these ports is vital to our economic prosperity. We depend on the export of goods nearly all of which have to be exported by sea. As an island nation we have no other option. Delays and disruption on the waterfront cripple the economy, which is something we can no longer afford. Since the Hawke Government came to power our international indebtedness has risen by $58 billion. It is still rising, by $11,000m a year. The tragic feature is that this vast increase in indebtedness has not been going into investment in new, productive enterprises. Due to the gross mismanagement of the economy by the Hawke Government it has been going into consumption expenditure. We have not got any useful value out of this enormous increase in our indebtedness.

Today, 64 per cent of our export earnings is required to pay the interest plus the repayments on our international indebtedness. We desperately need a rise in our export earnings. If we are going to export we must recognise that we are competing in a highly competitive field. If we wish to compete effectively, our exports must be of high quality, properly priced and our delivery must be reliable. Our ports play a crucial part in two aspects of that. Excessive port charges make them uncompetitive. In regard to reliability we must not have these random hold-ups in our ports. The nation as a whole suffers every time this occurs.

There has been a dramatic change in the last 20 years or so in the nature of our cargoes from the old miscellaneous loading of ships. Now the vast bulk of our exports goes either as bulk cargoes or as containers. So I will concentrate on the bulk cargoes and containers. With regard to bulk cargoes, my colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Michael Baume will be amplifying my remarks. It is worth looking at a recent report by the Royal Commission on Grain Storage, Handling and Transport which was a devastating indictment of government actions and union behaviour in regard to wheat handling, which is a critical part of our exports and, therefore, of the economic prosperity of all Australians. Not surprisingly, because this was a sensibly handled royal commission, it came to the conclusion that what had to be done in this field was to go for privatisation-not on any doctrinaire lines but because only by that means do we get competition and only by competition do we get efficiency.

Let me consider statistics for our grain handling terminals. In Sydney export handling is 17,000 tonnes per employee per year. In the United States it is 80,000. At the main terminal in Canada it is 120,000. I do not have time to go through all the many rorts that go on in these terminals, of which Senator Parer is well-informed, so I will just mention one-the idea that one closes down the whole terminal when the workers want to have a smoko together. The idea of staggering the smoko so that terminal loading operations can go on was not acceptable to the union. When the workers want to knock off together the whole expensive operation stops while everyone has a smoko. This is the sort of anti-social behaviour which adds enormous costs to our grain exporters, loses markets and costs the whole community very great hardships.

As the Royal Commissioner pointed out, what we must do in these terminals is get rid of some of the restrictive work practices and, in particular, the unnecessary industrial disputes. Far too many of the industrial disputes in our ports are not related to work conditions at all; they are political activities by waterfront unions trying to conduct our foreign policy for us-whether we should export to South Africa, what we should do about Fiji and so on. These matters have nothing to do with the management the unions are dealing with. They have nothing directly to do with the unions. This is an attempt by them to take over the conduct of our foreign policy. This must stop. The community as a whole suffers from this sort of behaviour because, quite apart from the extra costs involved, our reputation is seriously damaged. Not only is our reputation as an exporter damaged but also the costs are substantial. It was estimated by the Royal Commissioner that restrictive work practices and industrial disputes add $1.50 a tonne to export costs. That sort of amount can be crucial when one is dealing with and trying to export in a highly competitive market.

I turn now, as others will be dealing with the problem of bulk handling, to the question of containers. We all know that our waterfront is not performing well, but I do not think many people know how badly it is performing. Our container productivity-the rate at which we load and unload containers using essentially exactly the same equipment as other countries use-is about half that of more efficient ports in Asia and much lower than that of our trading partners. For instance, for every 100 containers handled in a given time in Australia-I repeat, by the same cranes, by the same equipment and with the same organisation-New Zealand handles 138 containers; the United Kingdom, 141; northern Europe, an average of 214; north America, 250; and Japan, 312. Using the same equipment, the Japanese unload containers three times as fast as we do. That is just not acceptable. If we do not load and unload our containers promptly our ships stay longer in port and our costs go up-and who pays them? First of all the exporters pay them but ultimately every Australian citizen suffers as a result of this sort of behaviour.

We have also become a legend for our strikes. It is a legend I do not like very much. These random strikes and unreliable delivery cause frustration and anger in our trading partners. This is probably the most damaging feature of our export performance. In 1987 alone there were 250 separate industrial disputes involving stoppages on the Australian waterfront, affecting about 360 ships. The costs to Australian exporters and importers were incalculable. One cannot work in this situation. If one gets an export order which is delayed on the waterfront for weeks or even months, one does not get another order. People are not prepared to put up with that sort of unreliable delivery, which is quite beyond the control of the would-be exporter. Of the 250 separate industrial stoppages, New South Wales, not surprisingly, for reasons I will come to in a minute, had nearly half-114 of them.

What has been happening over the years is that manning on Australian ships and on the wharves has reached a ludicrous stage through the power given to union monopolies. There is no sign of any serious diminution in manning numbers. This is a subject we must tackle. The point is that, in looking at our wharves, everyone knows what has to be done. I give the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) credit for knowing what must be done. However, I am not yet prepared to give him any credit for doing it. I will believe that when I see it. Nevertheless, he and I both know what must be done to sort out the problem on the wharves. We must eliminate the scope for demarcation disputes. We must eliminate the wildcat strikes on foreign policy grounds which have nothing to do with industrial conditions on the wharves but do great damage to our credibility as an export country. We must eliminate all the restrictive work practices which do not add anything to work safety or work satisfaction but have merely been imposed as a method of unions showing their power over management. We must get back to the doctrine of a fair day's work for a fair day's pay. In order to get the pressure from management to achieve this, we must have proper competition.

We all know these are the essences of what must be done. The question is: How do we achieve them? The solution of the Government is to set up another inquiry, this time an interstate commission. Over the years there has been inquiry after inquiry into the waterfront. The problem has been-this goes back to governments previous to the Hawke Government-that nothing much has been done. There are many entrenched interests on the waterfront-and not only the unions, by the way. Some aspects of management are also entrenched in maintenance of the present situation. This was perhaps acceptable, never satisfactory. Perhaps one could live with it while this country was economically performing fairly well. It was always a very damaging thing for our economy and always resulted in us living less well as a community than we should have. Perhaps one could argue that we must put up with this chaos on the waterfront because tackling it is going to be difficult and, after all, we can probably afford it. The Royal Commission on Grain Storage, Handling and Transport quoted Machiavelli. I think it is worth requoting him because there was a lot of truth in what he said. Machiavelli said:

It must be remembered that there is nothing more difficult to plan, nor more dangerous to manage than the creation of a new system. For the initiator has the enmity of all who would profit by the preservation of the old institutions and merely lukewarm defenders in those who would gain by the new ones.

That might be an acceptable explanation of why we have been so long as a nation in tackling the outrages and economic inefficiencies on the waterfront, but this is a luxury we can no longer afford. Since the Hawke Government came to power our economic situation has crumbled disastrously. Whether we could afford it before the Hawke Government came to power, it is quite clear that we can no longer afford it. The answer surely must be to tackle these problems, not address them, which is the remark the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) persists in making. I am not certain what he means by `addressing them'. I suppose he means talking to them. I would like to see him doing something about them.

The Minister, Senator Robert Ray, knows what must be done. I would like to see him doing it rather than setting up more inquiries. When one inquiry is completed there is lots of scope for a further inquiry, and the system goes on and on. What we need out of this economically inept Government is some action, not just talk and addressing problems, because the situation has deteriorated markedly in recent years. International indebtedness has ballooned disastrously and we must improve the performance of our waterfront so that we can export in order to have economic survival and, ultimately, recovery.

I would like to turn to the particular problems of Sydney and Botany Bay. Sydney has always been a poor port, but there is a particular problem arising there because of the crisis in the container unloading organisations. About 90 per cent of containers go to major organisations. The whole container goes to an organisation and is unloaded by it. Ten per cent of the containers have consignments to various small businesses and must be broken up and redistributed in depots. In January there was a backlog of 1,000 containers in Sydney. It has since risen to 1,500.

What is a worry is that the Ministers, first of all Senator Gareth Evans and now Senator Robert Ray, keep on saying that the situation is under control and it is all being fixed. I find two things worrying. The first is the damage being done to small businesses, because the people who deal with these unpacking depots in less than container loads are small business people who, for example, are importing material for clothing which they are going to export; people who are importing components which subsequently they are going to export. Small businesses are hit by these delays and we can hear the pathetic complaints of people who have had delays in consignments for a couple of months-apparently indefinitely-which to them are critical. The cynicism of the unions handling this is quite remarkable.

A couple of proposals have been made about trying to increase the flow through these container depots. One was that depots other than union approved depots, waterside worker approved depots, should be allowed to unpack these containers. That was resisted bitterly and has still not been achieved, although it is worth noting that the non-approved Waterside Workers Federation of Australia depots will unload a container for about half the price of a union approved depot, but people are not allowed to use them. Where we have this enormous backlog the union will not allow other depots to unpack containers even though they could do it. These are blackmail tactics on the Australian community as a whole. Then there was this suggestion, `All right, if we have problems unloading them and you insist on them being unloaded in union approved depots, let us work two shifts'. One would think that that would be very popular. The work is relatively unskilled. We have excessively high unemployment. The suggestion was, `Let us work two shifts'. Of course, the shift workers would get the shift loading. But the union would not approve that unless a concession was made that their annual leave went up from four weeks to five weeks-an extra week on full award pay plus 17 1/2 per cent holiday pay loading. The union would not agree to that unless it got an extra one week's leave for all its workers for something which, surely, should be a matter of automatic provision. Here is a problem; here is an obvious solution but the union says, `No, we will stand over the community and we will not permit this to happen unless you give us a payoff'. Why should a union be allowed to exert this sort of blackmail on the community? Why does the Government not do anything about it?

Senator Robert Ray, in answer to a question of mine yesterday, said quite accurately that this was not solely a Commonwealth responsibility; the State Government and its instrumentalities are heavily involved. They are. It is not surprising that the situation is far worse in New South Wales than it is in other areas of Australia. The reason is that we have a corrupt government in New South Wales that is heavily involved with militant union activities and will not stand up to them. We need a government that sees the problems-I can accept that the Government sees the problems-and is prepared to tackle them in the interests of the whole Australian community. This is what the country deserves from any Australian government. It is not getting it from this one.
