TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hamer talked for about 19 1/2 minutes on the matter of the waterfront and then got in a paid political advertisement at the end. I think that is not a bad effort for Senator Hamer one day before the New South Wales election. It is a pretty fair effort for him to do it in that way. There is no doubt that shipping and waterfront issues have been a cinderella issue in politics in recent years. At least I am encouraged to see that honourable senators opposite have raised it in a matter of public importance. I think it has been an underrated and grossly ignored area of importance in the Australian economy. Not enough attention has been given to it by Labor governments or previous Liberal governments. Senator Hamer had a variety of things to say, mostly in a general and a critical sense. Senator Hamer said that I knew the solutions; therefore, I should implement them. I am not sure, but I think he is giving me too much credit. I did not hear any solutions coming from Senator Hamer today.
—Privatise.

—I did not see any solutions when Senator Michael Baume and Senator Hamer were both rookie members of the House of Representatives from 1975 to 1977. Senator Hamer probably did not have to move to the Senate, but he did and someone of the same political persuasion won his seat. They had 7 1/2 years to tackle what we all admit were the same sorts of problems that exist today. It may well be that since 1982 those problems should have been addressed faster and more vigorously because of changed economic circumstances, but they have always been there. I make the point that it is a bit too easy just to say that the solution should be there. Senator Hamer referred to Machiavelli when suggesting a solution to the waterfront problems. Why does he think Machiavelli centred his activities in Florence and did not move to Venice? It was because there were no ports in Florence.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hamer referred to an economically inept government. I would love to be able to explore that in depth. I would love to make a comparison between the Hawke Labor Government and the Fraser Liberal Government, but that is another debate and we have had that on other occasions. However, I do say that when the Hawke Government came to power in 1983 and through to 1987 we were basically obsessed with getting the macroeconomic parameters right. We had to do that because of the economic circumstances at the time. Now we are equally determined to move on those microeconomic agendas that are so essential, of which shipping and waterfront are two.

I move to what the situation is in Sydney and then I will move to the longer term plans. We concede that there have been significant delays in unpacking less than full container load (LCL) consignments at the Sydney international container depots due to the following reasons: there was a closure in December at the Consolidated Cargo Services Pty Ltd depot due to a breakdown in negotiations on revised working arrangements; there was a merger in December of the depot operations of Freightbases Container depot and Liner Services Pty Ltd; there was a closure of the Liner Services site which was accompanied by some industrial action; there were also some problems with Darling Harbour being reserved for bicentennial activities; and there was a significant increase in less than full containers in the November-January period amounting to 20 per cent. There are currently approximately 1,500 containers waiting to be unpacked. The problem has had a serious impact on some small importers, with a number of employees reportedly being laid off.

Industrial agreements dating from the late 1960s have led to the development of two types of container depots in Australia. Firstly, we have the international depots which employ Waterside Workers Federation clerks and either Federated Storemen and Packers Union or Waterside Workers Federation operational labour. These types of depots can unpack and pack any international less than full container load shipments. Secondly, we have the Trans-Tasman depots which employ Transport Workers Union labour which can handle only LCL shipments associated with the New Zealand trade. There have been a number of meetings, however, between the Association of Employers of Waterfront Labour, depot operators, shipping companies, unions and users. Department of Industrial Relations and the Department of Transport and Communications officials have also attended some of these meetings. The Department of Transport and Communications has been working with importers to assist them in the clearance of urgent consignments. Discussions between industry participants have resulted in some progress in putting in place measures to deal with the container backlog.

The Consolidated Cargo Services depot at Rozelle reopened on 29 February following agreement with the Waterside Workers Federation on productivity-based employment arrangements. This has increased unpacking capacity by over 100 containers per week. In early March, Liner Freight Services at Villawood engaged additional casual storemen and packers. This, together with the use of overtime, has increased the throughput by 30 per cent, or 70 containers, to about 300 per week. In addition, depot unpacking facilities are expected to open at Australian National Line (ANL) Port Botany as from 21 March. I think this is slightly in conflict with what Senator Hamer was saying, but I have only had a fax on my desk today confirming that, so I attribute no acts of commission to him in that regard. This facility will have a throughput of about 40 containers per week. However, the proposal to establish a temporary unpacking operation at No. 6 Darling Harbour will now not proceed. The intended operator, Patrick Stevedoring Co., claims that there was not sufficient client interest to make the facility commercially viable. However, that decision could well have been dictated by industrial relations consequences.

Senator Hamer today said, `Look, we know what the problems are. Why don't we just wave a magic wand and do something about it?' Do we need another inquiry? Generally, I am pretty sympathetic to that approach. But one gets sick of people just saying, `There is a problem; let us have an inquiry'. I think we have to realise, though, that the last couple of inquiries in this area have progressed enormously. It was thought by the Government that one final inquiry would come up with the strategy required. So I do not think it is just a case of saying, `Look, we have a very hard problem; it is in the hard basket. Let us have another inquiry'. We have to be aware of the delicate matter of who has responsibility for this area. After all, a lot of ports are controlled by State governments. Therefore, using the Inter-State Commission was seen as a most appropriate device.

I will spend a little time detailing what the Government's waterfront strategy is and the sort of timetable that we expect will be adhered to this year. The Government's strategy to improve the efficiency, productivity and reliability and the industrial relations record of the Australian waterfront was announced in December 1986. The strategy was developed in response to issues identified in the final report of the industry task force on shore-based shipping costs. The strategy involves four industry groups and the Inter-State Commission. The primary focus of the strategy during 1987 involves the four industry groups identifying and, where possible, addressing problems in their separate areas of responsibility. The strategy entered into its second phase in February 1988 with the announcement of public hearings by the Inter-State Commission. These hearings are directed towards a formulation by the Commission of a broad package of measures to address the more deep-seated structural problems affecting the industry.

The structural adjustment committee of Cabinet met with the major participants in the waterfront strategy on 17 February 1988 to review progress in the strategy. Following this meeting, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) issued a media release on this subject. I have to say that Ministers were impressed by the evident commitment of all parties-and, remember, we have users, employers, unions and so on all involved in this process. We were fairly impressed by their willingness to work cooperatively to achieve change. Might I just interpose that that is why I see this final process as being so important. It will be much easier to make the changes necessary to get an efficient and reliable operation with the cooperation of everyone rather than confrontation. I think there is now a firm basis to expect that the strategy will result in agreements by the end of this year to a package of measures to achieve the significant improvements that I have talked about.

The Inter-State Commission has a threefold task in the strategy: monitoring other elements in the strategy, preparing a long term integrated plan for the industry and developing effective performance indicators for each sector of the industry. It provided the Government with an interim report on progress in September 1987. In accordance with normal procedures for Inter-State Commission inquiries, the Commission has called for submissions from interested parties, which are due by 25 March 1988. If Senator Hamer would like to put in a submission, he still has four or five days in which to do so. The Commission will be holding public hearings commencing on 7 March and then continuing from 28 March. The Commission is to provide a draft report to the Government in July 1988, outlining possible elements of an industry reform package. This will be followed by further public hearings and discussions aimed at achieving agreement on a broad package of measures required to improve the efficiency of the industry, which will be the basis of its next report in November. So the timetable we are outlining is: public hearings, a report, further public hearings and a final report some time in November and expected Government action immediately thereafter.

Something like four committees are working in this area. I might just go through the activities of some of them. The Stevedoring Industry Review Committee (SIRC) is made up of union and management representatives under the chairmanship of Sir John Moore. The Committee is addressing improvements to management and work practices in the stevedoring industry. The Committee concluded the first stage of its work program reviewing management work practices at the local level, with the settlement in October and November 1987 of the second tier agreement with three of the SIRC unions-the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia and the Stevedoring Supervisors Association. The agreement for the fourth union, the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union of Australia, is currently being concluded following a port by port review of wharf security arrangements.

The SIRC has now commenced the second stage of its program, examining designated national issues through a number of employer-union working parties. The issues include employment; deployment structures; mobility of labour between employers and between ports; the integration of labour classifications; development of career paths and training; communication, consultation and information sharing with the work force; performance standards and productivity; redundancy arrangements and job security measures. I think that is a fairly wide ranging area.

We then have the Industry Committee under the chairmanship of Mr Ian Webber, Managing Director of Mayne Nickless Ltd. It is addressing commercial impediments within the industry, including inadequate communication. The Committee's Sydney and Melbourne working parties identified a number of priority issues which were addressed by specific project teams. In a report to the Inter-State Commission in January 1988 Mr Webber indicated that he believed the working parties were reaching the limits of their effectiveness, although they are continuing, wherever possible, to implement recommended changes in consultation with industry. We can see there that the Industry Committee has taken the suggestions about as far as it can go.

We also have the Importer/Exporter Panel, which was formed under the chairmanship of Mr Ivan Deveson, Managing Director of Nissan Australia, to represent the views of customer industries. The Panel presented its final report to the Inter-State Commission in December 1987. The report concluded that fundamental reform was required of the waterfront, not just marginal improvements. These reforms included: a major restructuring package in the stevedoring industry; negotiation with the States on major port reforms; and the establishment of an organisation to market and operate inter-system rail freight services. The panel is continuing to monitor developments in the strategy from the perspective of client industries. Finally, we have the Australian Transport Advisory Council, which is a structure being used to pursue action in conjunction with State governments to deal with the problems in rail and port operations.

I will not go into any more detail on the work of the Inter-State Commission, other than to say that it is not only the strategy with which it will come up that is important; it will also be important that all groups be involved in the decision making, because that will mean the eventual implementation of a proper waterfront strategy in such a way as to get it in by a form of consensus.

Senator Hamer referred to manning levels and also included shipping. I draw the honourable senator's attention to some of the advantages of the Maritime Industry Development Council (MIDC) scheme. In fact within about one month's time the first MIDC ship, which has taken manning levels from 30 to 26 and now down to 21, will be on the run between, I think, Bunbury and Portland. The honourable senator, as a person with a lot of experience in this regard, would probably understand the developments made in that regard in terms of multi- skilling, having one mess and all those other features. I think it is a bit unfair on the Seamen's Union of Australia to say that no progress has been made in this area. In fact several hundred, almost 1,000 seamen's jobs have been lost in this country in the last few years. Yet they are still willing to support a scheme that will mean Australian ships with far less crew requirements. That comment was really an off-handed reference to shipping and we are basically dealing with the waterfront.

I acknowledge that there are problems on the waterfront and that they have to be tackled. I do not acknowledge, and I will not agree, that they can be fixed tomorrow or next week. However, they can be tackled in this calendar year, and they must be. I hope that everyone takes the same sort of relatively constructive approach as Senator Hamer, because out in the community-among newspapers and some organisations-there is a deliberate attempt to distort the existing situation and stir it up without really wanting a solution. I am referring to some of those people in the National Farmers Federation and elsewhere who think that by being gung ho and tough they can ensure that things will flow automatically.

The situation on the waterfront at the moment may not be the best, but it could get worse. But in terms of this country's future we need a cooperative approach wherever possible and not a mad, irrational confrontationist approach. I end my contribution by saying that the problems in Sydney are coming under control. I am not sure whether those problems have featured as a big issue in the New South Wales election campaign but before I sit down I wish all the Australian Labor Party candidates the best of luck tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this matter of public importance submitted by my colleague Senator Hamer, drawing attention to:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost to every Australian of inefficiencies, restrictive work practices and lack of competition on the Australian waterfront, highlighted by the continuing chaos on the Sydney docks.

I was pleased to hear the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) basically agree with the text of this matter of public importance and the words that he used about the method of tackling the problems. However, historically, his remarks may end up just as words even though Senator Ray probably believes them, but I doubt whether his Government will have the intestinal fortitude to confront the real issues.

Australia is an island continent with dozens of natural deep water ports. We are blessed with such ports and per head of population we are one of the major trading nations in the world. We export about 80 per cent of our primary production and mineral products. With those sorts of facilities and resources we should have one of the great merchant navies of the world, both for the interstate movement of goods and for exports. Yet, our international shipping is virtually non-existent, while our coastal shipping marginally survives only because it is protected by monopoly-like arrangements. Considering the facilities we have, our coastal shipping is really non-existent.

With few exceptions our ports are among the most costly and inefficient in the world. It is interesting to note that there are some efficient bulk ports, such as Port Hedland, Hay Point, Abbot Point and Gladstone. These are all run by free enterprise or as free enterprise organisations. Our foreign trading partners are well aware of the industrial mayhem on our waterfront. For example, in 1984, the Baltic and Maritime Conference urged its members to think twice about trading with Australia, while a South East Asian ship owner warned potential charterers to treat us as a `communist country or a war risk zone'. What a reputation to have! It is beyond belief that with comparatively small loadings, it is cheaper and more efficient to move goods on rubber tyres from Sydney to anywhere in Australia than it is by sea. This means that the cost to every Australian individual is enormous because it means funding a road system which would do justice to a country with a population about the size of that of the United States.

To appreciate the abysmal state of our waterfront, I give a few examples of the rorts, restrictions and sudden strikes with which a manufacturer must contend if he sends his goods by ship from Sydney. First, he contacts a truck operator to take his product to the port. When the trucker finds out that he is going to the port of Sydney he loads his charge by something up to 50 per cent because he knows he will be inevitably delayed when he arrives at the port. When the goods are loaded onto the vessel it will be done by a gang of 15 people, when three or four would do the job in the United Kingdom, the United States, Japan or almost any other country in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen?

—Fifteen, if you are lucky. Overmanning in Australian stevedoring gangs blows out the cost of loading and unloading goods. For instance, stevedoring charges cost one exporter of scrap metal $15 a tonne. This is simply to load it from the dock onto the ship. This compares with a stevedoring charge for the same exercise of $3 a tonne in the United States and 65c a tonne in the United Kingdom. There is every chance that, a business having decided to move goods around Australia by ship and having got the goods to the wharf, the ship will then be delayed in sailing because of industrial disputation caused by a maritime union objecting to some aspect of foreign policy, such as a coup in Fiji, the policies of the South African Government or the problems of any government. If those two examples are not pertinent at the time, the unions will make problems up. The Australian Chamber of Shipping found that half of the industrial disputes on the Australian waterfront in 1987 were related to foreign policy issues. Who is the Government of this country? I think we know the answer to that. So we have delays, and the demurrage costs for these delays can be anywhere between $5,000 and $25,000 a day. Who pays? Of course, every Australian individual consumer-every wage earner, every family man-pays.

SPEECH.PARA: The businessman might then find that the ship is crewed by Australian seamen who operate under the two-crew manning system. Under this system crews are rostered for 26 weeks at sea and 26 weeks leave a year-far in excess of leave allowances for crews in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. This means that every shipboard berth needs 2.25 personnel effectively to man the ship. Then, of course, a tug has to pull the ship away from the wharf. We find these very same conditions applicable to the crews of tugs, who never leave their home port. They are given the same conditions as if they were on an international run from here to Japan, Europe or wherever. The October 1986 report of the Maritime Industry Development Council entitled Moving Ahead states that as a result of this two-crew system our manning levels are more than double those of our trading partners. When the vessel arrives at the port of destination the same story will be repeated, except that it will be a mirror image of loading the goods on the ship, and the goods will have to run the gauntlet of the rorts and restrictions at the other end.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just within Australia.

—Just within Australia. The net result is that the manufacturer says, `To hell with this', and uses road transport. In the domestic market he is in a fairly happy position because competition is offered by road transport. On the export market, however, he has no choice unless he produces relatively small high value products which can be transported by the airlines. In that case, of course, he would use the airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: This country is, correctly, encouraging the growth of manufacturing in respect of both import replacement and exports. The collapse of the dollar, which reduced the comparative unit costs of labour in this country and at the same time reduced the purchasing power of every Australian for imported goods, should have given our manufacturing industry an enormous boost. There are many reasons why this did not eventuate in the way expected. There were some isolated cases of it occurring, and there were some improvements that we should all applaud. But a major impediment to the export of manufactured goods is our port costs and the disruption at the ports which deters buyers because, apart from costs, they can never be sure they will receive the goods when they need them.

We all know of stories about people who have lost export markets simply because of their inability to have goods delivered at the correct time. I think Senator Hamer referred to the example of a business's inability to get goods for remanufacture here for a particular fashion market in the necessary time, meaning that the export market was in danger of being lost. It probably was lost. A survey last year of overseas countries importing materials from Australia found that their inventory levels are approximately 50 per cent higher due to the unpredictability of the shipping and waterfront industry. In the car industry manufacturers are trying to trim inventories with the just-in-time system but the fear of bare assembly lines causes many to cling to the just-in-case system; this means carrying extra stock. The management at General Motors-Holden's Ltd says that car companies build in as much as 15 days inventory supply to offset delays on the waterfront. This stock is worth more than $30m to $40m. That is another inefficiency-a flow-on, if you like, a multiplier effect-in the devastation caused by the inefficiency of the waterfront.

The simple fact is that until we are able to lift the efficiency of our waterfront, both with respect to unit costs and reliability, we do not stand a ghost of a chance of improving our export of manufactured goods, which means continued balance of payments deficits and the continued loss of thousands of jobs for Australians in areas where we need to provide more jobs to give us a better industrial base in Australia.

Just the costs of unreliability and uncertainty are at least as important as the direct costs at the waterfront. A graphic example of this was given in the report of the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, tabled in this place on Wednesday. The report noted that the Centre for Transport Policy Analysis estimates that a premium of $2 a tonne is added to shipping freight charges for grain because of Australia's industrial environment. In the five years to 1986-87 Australia has exported about 17.5 million tonnes of grain, mostly wheat. So this $2 per tonne premium is unnecessary and has cost the industry some $35m for one of our major exports.

Senator Robert Ray spoke about the waterfront strategy. He took what on the face of it appeared to be a fairly reasoned view that he himself did not like committees but he thought that in the long run it would be helpful to have this final committee. I wonder how many final committees we have had going back over the years. He also referred to four committees currently reporting or having just reported. I have to say that I wonder seriously about this. The Government must know the problems. Everyone knows that the Hawke Labor Government is totally out of touch, but surely it cannot be out of touch to the extent that it does not know what is going on at the waterfront, the Achilles heel of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are pretty incompetent, so they probably do not know.

—Maybe Senator Messner is right on that. Just the other night I heard the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Mr Bill Kelty, say, `We won the last election'. The problem is that the very people who through their irresponsibility and industrial vandalism brought this country to its knees in the 1970s are now in government. Perhaps it is poetic justice that they are now charged with the job of trying to sort out the mess they created over the decade when the current Prime Minister was the President of the ACTU.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we list the sorts of unproductive restrictive work practices, rorts, call them what you like, that go on, so that people are aware of them. As the Government does not appear to know that it is having an inquiry, we will give it a few indications. On the subject of non-productive working time, in the container terminals employees work a 35-hour week, but when meal breaks, smokos, shower time and walking time are deducted from their working hours, that figure comes down to 27 hours a week on full pay.

On the subject of idle time, workers are kept at the ports at maximum levels through down periods in order to have sufficient manning levels at peak times. On the subject of strikes, Australia has topped an international shipping insurer's strike club statistics-fancy that-for eight years in a row for having the highest number of claims related to industrial disputes. In 1987 more than half the disputes on the waterfront were over non-work related matters-objections to what was going on in South Africa and Fiji.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this some South American country you are talking about?

—It sounds like Mr Keating's banana republic or Senator Walsh's Argentinean road. The Australian waterfront is the Achilles heel of Australia. Sydney is by far the worst area in this country for industrial disputation, featherbedding, overmanning and rorts. Interestingly enough, two Labor governments-State and Federal-blame the other and say, `It is not our problem; it is your problem'. They are attempting to pass the buck, to do a Pontius Pilate in this regard and it is not good enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question but that this is an extremely serious issue that has been brought up for debate in the Parliament today. I do not wish to detract from its seriousness, but as we all realise that the subject of this debate is not about problems on the Australian waterfront but the New South Wales elections tomorrow, I commence my contribution by offering my best wishes to the success of my Labor colleagues in New South Wales tomorrow. That is what this discussion is all about. I will be very pleased when next week rolls around and the election is over. Australia's Achilles heel at the moment is not the waterfront; it is the Federal Opposition. There is not much question about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting aspect about the debate so far has been this: one would get the impression from all the speakers opposite that all the serious and structured problems that beset Australia's waterfront happened yesterday. The fact is that these serious problems go back to the 1960s when containerisation was first introduced in this country and, in terms of some of the more deeply entrenched problems, considerably before then. It is interesting to note the laissez-faire attitude of those opposite when they were in government in terms of their record. They came in here today and started jumping up and down, trumpeting and screaming and yelling about what this Federal Government should do about it-indeed, this Federal Government is doing something about it-but the only thing on their track record to cope with the same problems was to have a laissez-faire attitude towards them. In 1977 their brilliant initiative was to hand the whole thing over to self-regulation. What a brilliant and successful strategy that turned out to be! It is the only thing on the track record of those opposite which is to their credit.

The alternative view is very starkly displayed in this country in that this Government is not just tackling the structural problems on the waterfront. As those opposite know, to their discomfort, this Government is tackling successfully the entire restructuring of the whole industry base in Australia-not just on the waterfront but in the car industry, the steel industry and elsewhere. It has done so with a remarkable degree of success which, I predict, this Government will achieve on the waterfronts of Australia also. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) issued a public statement as recently as February this year which talked about the progress that has been made to date with the structural readjustment program that the Government is overseeing on the waterfront problems in Australia. In the opening paragraph of the February release, the Prime Minister announced:

The Structural Adjustment Committee of Cabinet met today with the principal players in Australia's waterfront industry. The reduction of shore-based shipping costs is crucial to Australia's international competitiveness, and a central element in the Government's general economic reform strategy.

I might say that it is a successful economic reform strategy. Those opposite always solve their industrial relations problems not by talking to the players concerned but by legislating against them-just like they did in Queensland. What we have as a result is not economic progress but anarchy.

The Minister has spoken in detail of what is being done by this Government. The Inter-State Commission (ISC) is cooperating with the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee (SIRC) to make recommendations to the Government as to the restructuring of the waterfront situation. It might be useful for honourable senators to know what that is all about. The Stevedoring Industry Review Committee was not established for this purpose. It was established in July 1986 by stevedoring employees and unions as part of the 1986 stevedoring award settlement. Because of the constructive work that it then did it was decided to continue its role in the restructuring proposal. The first stage of the work was completed last year. The report has been given to the Government. The second stage of its work has now been commenced.

The first stage was successful. It involved a series of meetings at major ports around Australia between April and August 1987 to review the restrictive work practices that we have been hearing so much about this afternoon. As I said, the second stage is now in place. It will involve an examination at the national level of a number of designated issues, including the mobility and integration of labour, the development of career paths and training, improved work force consultation, the enhancement of performance standards and redundancy measures. The examination will also concentrate on progress regarding the issue of training and career path development on the waterfront, that is, treating it as a career to improve waterfront morale. The SIRC parties have agreed that a major element in any reform package will be the development of appropriate training programs, increased multiskilling and career opportunities in the restructured waterfront industry.

The Association of Employers of Waterside Labour and the Australian Council of Trade Unions recently met with the ISC and agreed that an in-depth study should be undertaken by an expert consultant on the needs of the industry in relation to this extremely important issue.

Like other speakers in the debate so far, I do not want to suggest that I am not mindful of the short term problems that are currently being experienced in Sydney. They are very serious problems indeed, particularly for the small importers. I give some credit to Senator Hamer for the diligent way in which he has pursued this issue, as the Hansard record will demonstrate. A major problem, particularly for small businesses, concerns the partly loaded containers which have been held up for an inordinate period. The Government has been concentrating on this issue. Government officials have been working closely with industry participants to ensure the smooth introduction of industry measures to bring the container depot backlog problems in Sydney under control. The latest industry estimates are that with the additional capacity at Liner Freight Services at Villawood, the opening of the Australian National Line facility at Botany Bay and the improved performance of the P and O group Rozelle depot since re-opening in February, the number of containers awaiting unpacking should return to normal levels within about four weeks. I certainly hope that is the case.

The Opposition's record in government on this issue is a very sorry one. The only initiative it took to deal with these deeply structured problems was to take its hands off the entire industry, to forget it was there, to leave it to self-regulation, an attitude of, `You sort it out for yourselves'. We are now reaping the benefits of enlightened policies such as that. The other side is now preaching to us that we are doing nothing about it when I have demonstrated that the waterfront situation is now being treated in the same manner as the special committee of the Cabinet has been dealing with the entire restructuring necessary for the whole of Australian industry.

I conclude by saying, in response to Senator Hamer's remarks about `this economically inept Government', that I support what Senator Ray said earlier in the debate when he said that those strategies are working. I share Senator Hamer's and Senator Ray's concern about never-ending inquiries and the belief that the solution to any problem is to set up another inquiry. However, the fact is that the investigations and the restructuring that have taken place in other major industries in Australia have reaped positive economic benefits. We all know that with goodwill from all parties-it is essential if we are to get anywhere with anything that we have that-that the, I must say, overdue restructuring of the front line of Australia's import and export business, the waterfront, achieves the same degree of success.

With respect, I do not think that Senator Hamer has much ground for talking about an economically inept government. As was just revealed the other day, the fact is that this Government has successfully created one million new jobs in just five years of government. That has not been accidental. That has not been as a result of serendipity. That has not been fortuitous. It has been as a result of the intense concentration this Government has given to industry restructuring. It has created those one million jobs mainly because of the successful outcome of those efforts. It has brought unemployment down to about 7 1/2 per cent. That is far from satisfactory, but a great improvement on the previous figures. In regard to economic management, I must say with some degree of personal feeling, in terms of the people I represent in the Northern Territory, that the Government has done so at the same time as it has introduced the family allowance package for the people who need money most. For those who do not know about the family allowance package-and a lot of us could be forgiven for not knowing about this reform, because none of us in this chamber are eligible for it--

—The fact is that the positive results of industry restructuring are there to be seen. That is all they want so that they can pick up a few points, on this occasion this afternoon for the benefit of their embattled colleagues in New South Wales.
—Who is embattled?

—I think that we are down to desperation stuff if the debate in the Senate yesterday is anything to go by. That package of support for low income earners in Australia is, I point out to honourable senators opposite, in respect of families who need it most-the average family of a husband, wife and three children, earning around $300 a week-and has resulted in the equivalent of $100 a week in additional salary. Bill Kelty said about this package-and this is pretty heady praise from the union movement-that it has been a reform achieved by this Government in one Budget that has put into the pockets of people who need it money that would have taken the union movement 50 years to achieve with industrial action. That is what Bill Kelty said about it. I ask Senator Michael Baume: `Why have we been able to do that?'. I will tell him why. It is because of the success of this Government's concentration on restructuring industry in this country-not just on the waterfront but across the board. As a result, the Government has been able to bring down a budget with a zero deficit. That is the reason we have been able to do things such as that. The Australian community is the beneficiary of it. It is called good government.

SPEECH.PARA: I close by saying that I share the concern of all honourable senators in this chamber about the serious situation on Australia's waterfront and, in particular, the very serious situation in the Sydney ports. The fact is that this Government is moving positively to do something about it. I hope that on receipt of the report in July from the people who are working on this, the Government will succeed in introducing a restructuring of the waterfront in Australia that has been as successful as the restructuring of industry that has been carried out by this Government so far.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hamer's matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost to every Australian of the inefficiencies, restrictive work practices and lack of competition on the Australian waterfront highlighted by the continuing chaos on the Sydney docks.

Anyone listening to Senator Collins would have noted that he was certainly not on the wharves, he was more all at sea, particularly in the last section of his speech. It is intriguing to hear both him and the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) say that the Opposition has no record to be proud of in this area. On two scores he is totally wrong: in the first place, when this Opposition was in government the man who was the head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Bob Hawke--

TALK.START.PARA: —A vandal.

—He was an economic vandal, as my colleague Senator Parer has said. In Opposition we have consistently been pressing this Government, as have our New South Wales colleagues, on this essential matter of the waterfront in Australia. We have been making recommendations particularly on getting rid of restrictive work practices, privatising the operation and making genuine competition available in that area whereas the Labor Government in Canberra has been talking for five years. For 12 years the Labor Government in New South Wales has been doing other things which appear to relate much more to the back hip pocket than they do to decent administration and cleaning up both the wharves and the corruption which has abounded in that State. I think that we should look at exactly what 12 years of Labor government in New South Wales and five years of Labor government in Canberra have brought to this industry. Let me quote what the Maritime Services Board of New South Wales warned only a few weeks ago. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales ports will face catastrophe unless the backlog of uncleared LCL (less than container load) containers at Sydney's depots is cleared up within a few weeks . . .

That was on 22 February. That container backlog has not been cleared, it has worsened. So the catastrophe that the Maritime Services Board warned would take place is, in fact, taking place. It is a catastrophe for people, small businesses in particular, who have large amounts of money involved in idle stock, in vital parts for their manufacturing process and in the many other items that are being nonsensically and improperly delayed as a result of maladministration at both State and Federal levels. This has been getting worse at a time when, for deliberate, disgraceful and dishonest political purposes, this Government and the New South Wales Government have been pretending that it is getting better. Senator Collins got up here a few moments ago and said, `Oh, in a couple of weeks all the backlog will have gone'. I remind the honourable senator that in February when the New South Wales election was announced, a strange statement came from Senator Gareth Evans in this place. When Senator Hamer raised this matter, he said, `Don't worry, everything will be all right'-the New South Wales election was four weeks away-`because in four weeks the backlog will be cleared'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks.

—I am sorry, he said that it would be cleared in two weeks-before the New South Wales election. That statement could not possibly have been right at the time and no one with any knowledge of that industry or that problem could have properly pretended that the statement was right. It was a base and disgusting political stunt aimed at hosing down yet another example of incompetence in New South Wales and, of course, another example of the failure of the two Labor governments in Canberra and Sydney to solve problems that have been manifestly in evidence for such a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: But this disgraceful performance in this chamber by Ministers coming in with information that the most simple inquiry could have demonstrated was patently false, and which was delivered with the purpose of misleading the voters of New South Wales, is intolerable. I only hope that the people of New South Wales will recognise that the disastrous problems on the waterfront-the catastrophe, according to the Maritime Services Board in New South Wales-has been covered up by a conspiracy between Labor Ministers in the Federal Parliament and Labor Ministers in the State Parliament deliberately to mislead the people. The fact is that this backlog has not improved-not on your life! It has now got considerably worse. As the Maritime Services Board said three weeks ago:

The stage is being reached where it will become impossible for the Board to keep shipping and cargo handling operations in the ports isolated from the troubles that are occurring farther down the line-

that is, with the less than container load containers, 1,500 of which are now clogging the few container depots which, as Senator Hamer says, are allowed to operate by union fiat. Unless the union lets a depot work, it cannot; it is not allowed to handle these containers. Even Senator Ray admitted that. He said that different unions look after different depots. There is one union that looks after trans-Tasman trade. It is not allowed to handle containers from any other destination. If it did, the result would be a demarcation dispute-an inter-union dispute. Who pays for the inter-union dispute? The people of Australia pay for it. The costs are borne by ordinary Australians. The Maritime Services Board also went on to say that it was concerned that New South Wales ports would suffer a long term loss of trade because numbers of importers with cargoes caught up in the congestion might in future seek to route their goods through interstate ports. Of course, that is already happening. I noticed an item the other day which reported that the Brisbane board, which apparently has a far more efficient operation than that of New South Wales, is now out to attract Sydney cargo. This report said:
Over the next few days the Port of Brisbane Authority and the Brisbane Port Users Group will be attempting to persuade Sydney's business community to send its LCL goods through Brisbane.

Sydney's importers, who have been forced to wait up to eight weeks and longer for the delivery of LCL goods, will be told-in these advertisements that are to appear soon-that in Brisbane their cargo can be unpacked within a few days of discharge.

I draw to the attention of the voters of New South Wales the fact that Queensland does not have a Labor government. I suppose that one could say to those importers or those people awaiting goods that are in containers at ports, `If there is one simple positive thing you can do about getting your goods delivered, it would be to make certain you do not have a Labor government in New South Wales', at least on the evidence of this report from Queensland.

As I see it, the interesting thing about Senator Gareth Evans's claim that within a couple of weeks the problem would be overcome is that since that statement the number of containers in the backlog has increased by 50 per cent. These delays are sending many small businesses to the wall. Wholesalers and retailers in the seasonal industries, of course, are dramatically affected. But on top of that, Australian manufacturing exporters are also being affected because imported components are now being subjected to these excessively long and ludicrous delays. Bans, stoppages, demarcation disputes, outdated work practices and so on have turned the Sydney docks and container depots into a sort of industrial disaster area.

The small businesses that are being crippled with these two-month delays on the waterfront are getting no special relief from anyone. They are getting no special relief through any action by either the State or the Federal Labor governments. There is plenty of talk-talk, talk, talk. Senator Hamer pointed out that there is a lot of talk. Senator Robert Ray agreed, but added that this time the talk would lead to something. Twelve years of a State Labor government has led us nowhere except to crisis point, and five years of this Labor Government has simply led us to more talk. Bankruptcy is facing so many of these people who are caught, who are the unwitting victims in this disgraceful situation. I have here a letter which outlines the problem as it was only a week or so ago. The letter reveals to me the following:

One depot has, either on site or at terminals awaiting movement to the depot, about 1250 containers to be unpacked. On current figures these containers alone will take 37 working days (nearly 8 weeks) to unpack plus the additional containers that are arriving in that period.
Another depot has a backlog of about 400 containers-a delay here of about 31 working days (nearly six weeks).
Some depots are arranging Saturday unpacking for a fee of $115. This will do little except force everyone to pay an additional $115. There are already more requests than can be handled.

This is seen by many people as a sort of bribe or inducement to pay an extra $115 to get their containers handled. The intriguing thing is that in the time taken to handle 10 containers at Australian ports, 14 are handled in the United Kingdom, 20 in Singapore, 21 in northern Europe, 25 in North America and 30 in Japan. Here we are falling steadily behind. Senator Robert Ray says, `Everything is being fixed up. We've got some temporary arrangements'. Half of these arrangements have come undone. Whose fault is it? Senator Robert Ray was very revealing about that. In an answer to Senator Hamer yesterday he said:
. . . these matters are not strictly Federal matters . . .

In other words, `Don't blame us; it's the State Government's fault'. I repeat that, when pressed on this chaos, this disaster, Senator Robert Ray, as the responsible Minister in the Hawke Labor Government, said, `These matters are not strictly Federal matters'. Whose are they? When we ask Mr Sheahan, the relevant Minister in New South Wales, he says, `I've got no power to act'. I quote from a recent newspaper report:

The NSW Minister for Transport, Mr Terry Sheahan, was yesterday quick to respond to calls by the waterfront industry to intervene in the clearance of LCL jamming Sydney's depots by pointing out he had no legal authority to take action.

After 12 years of continuing problems on the waterfront-we heard from the Labor speakers today that there have been continuing problems; they complained about the previous Liberal Government not solving them-after 12 years of Wran-Unsworth mess, Mr Sheahan says that he has no legal authority to take action. The article went on to say:
. . . while Mr Sheahan is sympathetic to the crisis legally he could not intervene . . .
Mr Sheahan is reported as saying:
The delays are occurring in the privately owned depots . . .

The unions are involved in restrictive work practices and some extraordinary standover tactics. Mr Sheahan was asked by the private sector to step in and direct that this backlog be removed. The article stated:
On restrictive work practices and demarcation disputes, the Minister's spokesman said that all three unions involved . . . were all under the Federal Award.

Here we have a scandalous situation which is bringing disaster to many small businesses in Australia and inconvenience to many Australians who are awaiting shipments. It is causing massively increased costs to those who will be receiving the benefits of those imports. All those things are happening. On the one hand the Federal Government says that it is not its fault and on the other hand the State Government says that it is not its fault. Both are Labor governments, both have been there too long, and there is no doubt when we look at the crisis on the wharves in New South Wales that it is time for a change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the Senate this afternoon allows one to talk about the impact the waterfront chaos in Sydney is having on Australian families. The matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The cost to every Australian of inefficiencies, restrictive work practices and lack of competition on the Australian waterfront highlighted by the continuing chaos on the Sydney docks.

I want to stress the impact this is having on every Australian. Within the area in which I take an interest, I know of the growing number of families who are not able to obtain housing since Labor has been in government. The number of people now on the waiting list for government houses has grown dramatically in the five years since Labor has been in office. In the vicinity of 100,000 families are now in the queue for public housing who were not there in 1983. A large number of people are waiting for government assistance in order to purchase houses. The number is much larger than previously has been the case.

We know about the public hospital queues of people waiting for medical attention. We know that 100,000 Australians are waiting for surgery in the government hospital system. All of this flows from the fact that Australia is no longer competitive. The economy cannot afford to provide Australians with the sorts of services we believe they should have. In fact, the numbers are far greater now than when the Liberal Government was thrown out of office in 1983. Labor should be thoroughly ashamed to go to the polls in the New South Wales election with this record around its neck, a record of so many Australians suffering as a consequence of its five years of administration.

As the New South Wales election has been mentioned this afternoon, it is appropriate that some of these things should be brought forward. Health services now are worse than they have been for 30 or 40 years in this country. There are far fewer facilities and beds in the public hospital system. Far fewer procedures and services are available through the Medicare system. Far fewer pharmaceuticals are now provided than was the case previously. Of course, people know that these days they have to pay $10 for a prescription they used to be able to obtain much more cheaply and much more readily.

Many families have been forced out of the private hospital system because they cannot afford to pay the cost of private health insurance in addition to what they have to pay by way of the Medicare levy. That levy, which was one per cent, is now 1.25 per cent. In fact, the cost is about 3.15 per cent of income, with the rest being paid out of the taxation system. The reality is that there are many thousands of families without private cover who cannot get what they need by way of health services under the Medicare system. It is a complete myth to suggest that under Labor everybody is covered for health care. They may appear to be, but those who are sick know that that is not the case. Those who are sick, or whose elderly family members are sick, know just how difficult it is to get health care.

The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) talks in the other place about people booking for surgery. He does not seem to realise that people do not book for something they do not need. It is very disruptive of family life to have to wait a couple of years for a hip replacement or a prostate gland operation or for so many other things. A breadwinner may well be out of work for a long time, not being able to pursue employment because he is awaiting surgery. The Minister for Community Services and Health would tell us that such a person is on a booking list, as though this is something that one would choose to have done over a weekend. This is what has happened to Australia in the five years since Labor was elected in 1983.

I have referred to housing, to the number of people who are homeless or living in caravans and who would prefer to have their own homes. But what about the effect on a family having to live first here and then there as and when they are able to obtain employment or housing? They have to move from one place to another and take their children to different schools. They have to make new friends, establish new contacts in the community and perhaps they have to get a new doctor and get to know new people who will provide the services that they are accustomed to. That is completely disruptive to family life. The children in that situation do not have the same opportunity to establish social contacts and to become socially mature. They are constantly being put into new classes and having to get used to new people around them. They have very little chance to get an education that will enable them to get on in the world, to obtain employment and satisfaction and pleasure from what they will be doing in their lives.

I think those who glibly refer to the figures in relation to housing, without really considering the implications of having to move frequently, have no idea at all about what it means to those involved. It shows a complete lack of care. We hear about equity and justice and a great many other things, but the Australian Labor Party has very sorely let down the people of Australia in not being able to provide the sort of stability that many on lower incomes would want. Many single parent families know exactly what I am talking about.

The matter of public importance that we are discussing-the cost to every Australian of the inefficiencies and restrictive work practices on the Sydney docks-is real to this population. I hope that the people of New South Wales will think about these things tomorrow when they go to the polls, because they surely will have an opportunity then to say to the Labor Party exactly what they think about the way they have been let down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in this debate. I have been thunderstruck today to hear all the problems we have on our waterfront, and I hope that the people of Australia who have been listening to this debate have also been thunderstruck. The malpractices occurring on our waterfronts, and particularly in Sydney, have been costing us literally billions of dollars a year. This fact has been stressed today, and I am pleased to discuss it in light of the New South Wales State election tomorrow. I hope that people are well aware that due to what their local State Government and the Federal Government are doing, costs are increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the number of inquiries that have been suggested to try to rectify the situation, but that will not fix the waterside problems because the waterside workers have all the muscle. Redundancy is what they are on about. Listening to Senator Parer today talking about featherbedding, double handling and the time off, particularly at Newcastle, with Friday afternoons off and early knocking off times and the numbers of malpractices that are occurring on our waterfronts today, should make us feel ashamed to face the world. To hear that it is more expensive to transport materials from one Australian port to another than it is to ship them overseas, is horrifying.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes longer to unpack a container here than to bring it from Europe.

—That is right. I know that the Australian Customs Service has been trying to speed up and streamline its activities to get things through the wharves. But until we can fix our waterfront problems this country will not go ahead and prosper as it should. The oncosts that are being put on people because of this are shameful.
—It is worse in New South Wales than in any other State.

—That is right, but the people in New South Wales have a chance to express their dissatisfaction tomorrow, and so they should. They should give their Government a clear indication that they want something positive done to fix this problem-something like what was done in Queensland with the problem concerning the electricity unions. Contrary to what the Labor Party senators mentioned in the debate this afternoon it has not resulted in problems in Queensland; in fact, it has solved problems. I think the rest of Australia could take a good look at what has happened in Queensland in facing up to union malpractices. Also it gives a good idea of how to commercialise government authorities because now we in Queensland can let contract work; the contract is carried out on an economic basis and when it is finished we are not left with a huge bureaucracy. That is the end of that contract, then we let another one. That is one of the easy ways in which privatisation could be started off in Australia. I have innumerable quotes here from newspapers. The first is from the Daily Telegraph on 19 February which refers to the New South Wales State Transport Minister, Terry Sheahan, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the New South Wales Cargo Facilitation Committee-
That is another one of these bodies with very nice names--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are the ones which tell the lies.
—Quite right. The quote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: -which represents unions, importers and the Government-is investigating the delays as a matter of urgency.

Mr Sheahan said that what was needed was `a little less investigation and a lot more action'. He is dead right there! There was a call on 21 January to curb the wharf unions again in New South Wales, particularly in Sydney. I shall read a little quote from the New South Wales Waterside Workers Secretary who said:
`If you wander down to Darling Harbour, you'll see lots of commercial berths filled by tall ships.
`The Government should be spending money on making the ports more efficient, rather than on circuses like that.'

Then there was a media release by Senator Fred Chaney about the crisis on the Sydney waterfront. He wondered about the lethargy shown by the waterside workers on the docks. In answer to a question in the Senate, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) said he was considering a police investigation into the waterfront. That is another one. I do not know what the police will do.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had one of those. It was called the Costigan inquiry.

—Yes, we had one of those. It was supposed to be into the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia and it wound up on the bottom of the harbour. The union is going on just as merrily as before. We have an enormous backlog at our ports because of these activities. What is the good of the Australian Customs Service speeding up its operations when there is a backlog of containers and part containers at the ports. This is ruining the smaller businesses and some of the larger ones.

SPEECH.PARA: At Sydney's four major unpacking terminals there is a backlog of months, not just weeks. Some of the smaller importers have had to be closed because of the backlog. The unions are forcing this backlog because they want to negotiate terms and conditions for more featherbedding in a crisis situation. Businesses are going broke and are likely to give in to anything. I see the waterfront as a Chicago-style muscle operation that is cruelling the pitch in Australia and I urge all honourable senators to support the Opposition's urgency motion today. I hope that the people of Australia-and particularly those of New South Wales-have woken up to the conniving between the Government and the unions which is really destroying our economy.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief comments upon this matter. I do so after having had the benefit recently of attending a conference in Newcastle of the H. R. Nicholls Society of which I have the honour to be President. At this conference a number of fascinating industrial relations questions were being discussed. The reason for the choice of Newcastle as the venue for that conference was that probably no single city in Australia has suffered more in recent times from the depredations of the trade union movement-or of the trade union bosses.

—I defer. Senator Michael Baume points to Wollongong and there is a powerful argument for that point of view. Let Wollongong and Newcastle contest the honour. SPEECH.PARA: But I have to say that although that is still the case the activities recently on the Sydney waterfront are bidding fair to put Sydney also up there to take the flag. TALK.START.PARA: —It destroyed our export credibility.

—That is the better looking of them.

—That is the better looking of them, as Senator MacGibbon quite rightly says. My credentials in this matter are obviously good. If I were a parochial Queenslander like Senator Jones, Senator Burns or Senator Reynolds-we have a whole battery of Queenslanders on the other side of the chamber, for a change-I would be welcoming this development. I would be welcoming the demise of the port of Sydney because nothing will so quickly kill off the commercial viability of a great sea port-which Sydney undoubtedly is-than activities of the kind we have been hearing about this afternoon on its waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course if Sydney is to be killed off by activities of that kind, where will the trade go? It will go to other ports such as Brisbane and Melbourne-but I suspect more to Brisbane because Melbourne is not without its problems, too, as we are all well aware. I have been living in Queensland for the past 12 months and it is extraordinary that I cannot remember one strike during the whole of that time. There may have been one for 24 or 48 hours on the coalfields about some particular matter or other but apart from that I cannot remember a strike in Queensland during that time. I lived in Melbourne for 2 1/2 years before that and there was a strike every second week. If there was not one on the buses there was one on the trams, on the railways, in the ports or at the State Electricity Commission of Victoria.

The activity going on in this area is a disgrace to Australia, a disgrace to the trade union movement and a disgrace to the Government. It has been pointed out by earlier speakers this afternoon that one of the difficulties in this exercise is finding out who is supposed to be responsible. I agree that there are some divisions of responsibility in this area and it is perfectly true that not only is the Commonwealth responsible but also the New South Wales Government must bear its more than full share of the blame. Nevertheless, the fact that it is hard, once again, to attribute final responsibility as between a Labor government in New South Wales and a Labor government in Canberra does not mean to say we should not attribute any responsibility at all to anyone, which seems to be the view coming from the Government, from the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Robert Ray), who spoke earlier in the debate, and from others on that side of the chamber.

My belief is that the Government is very much to be condemned for the fact that this situation has been going on in Sydney for a very long time now and had it not been for the matter being raised by this side of the chamber we would never have heard about it in this place. The Government has been doing its best to keep quiet about it ever since these practices began. Meanwhile, business people in Sydney-particularly small business people, as I think Senator Sheil observed when he referred to part container loads-are going out of business. They simply cannot get their goods cleared through the ports. They have orders and contracts. They have made promises to their customers and their customers will go back to them when the orders that they are waiting on are three months late because the customers are also businessmen waiting to get on with their business of supplying their customers. It is a disgrace.

Mr Unsworth made a big fellow of himself by invoking the emergency powers in New South Wales to deal with a matter which was going to affect very much the whole breadth of voters in New South Wales. But has he stirred a single finger on this matter? The problem affects only the business community in New South Wales and he does not care about the business community in New South Wales. He does not care about the small business people in New South Wales.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the expression `another person' as used in paragraph (9) of section 160zh (9) of the Income Tax Assessment Act include `The Crown'.

(2) For the purpose of the capital gains tax legislation, is the cost base of a new lease from the Crown which has been granted upon the expiry of a previous lease over the same (or substantially the same) area held by that lessee, the market value of that new lease as at the date of commencement of such a new lease.

(3) Does section 160zu of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 operate so as to deem an acquisition by the lessee of a `fresh lease' (being a lease from the Crown for a term of 20 years) by virtue of the automatic extension granted by the Land Act Amendment Act passed by the Queensland Parliament on August 27, 1986 to be the acquisition of a new lease; if not, does any other section of this Act.

(4) If the answer to (3) is `yes'; (a) when is the lessee deemed to have acquired the fresh lease (that is, is the acquisition deemed to have occurred upon the expiry of the original lease or on the passing of the relevant `extending' legislation); and (b) what is the cost base and indexed cost base to the lessee for his deemed acquisition of the `fresh lease' (that is, is it the market value of the fresh lease as at the date of the expiry of the original lease or is it the market value of the fresh lease (if any) as at the date of the passing of the relevant legislation).

(5) If the lessee of a pastoral holding is deemed to have acquired the ``fresh lease'' created as a result of the automatic extension conferred by statute for a `nil' cost base, then is the whole of the proceeds of sale received on the disposal of the pastoral holding during the period of the 20 year extension subject to capital gains tax; if so, what action is being taken, either by amendment of legislation or issue of appropriate rulings, to ensure that assessments on this basis do not issue.

(6) For the purpose of the capital gains tax legislation, what is the cost base to the lessee of a new lease from the Crown which was issued to that lessee in exchange for the agreed surrender by the lessee of a previous lease over the same (or substantially the same) area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable Senator is referred to my press release of 28 January 1988 in which I announced that the Government has decided to amend the capital gains tax provisions in relation to Crown leases. In particular, rollover relief is to apply on the renewal, extension or conversion of a Crown lease of land made since 19 September 1985 where the new or extended lease is over the same or substantially the same land. This will have the effect of preserving capital gains tax exempt status where the original Crown lease was acquired before 20 September 1985 and, in other cases, of ensuring that no capital gains tax liability arises until the lease is disposed of to a third party or is otherwise terminated.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 October 1987 (Hansard, page 936), Senator Coulter asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer concerning the tax deductibility of expenditure on tobacco advertising including, in particular, expenditure by the tobacco industry on an advertising campaign to prevent the enactment of legislation in Victoria to ban such advertising. The Treasurer has supplied me with the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of Taxation, who is responsible for the administration of the taxation laws, advises that costs related to the normal advertising of a company's products are deductible for income tax purposes under the general deduction provisions of the income tax law. Those provisions authorise the allowance of a deduction to a taxpayer for outgoings incurred in deriving assessable income or necessarily incurred in carrying on a business for that purpose, to the extent that they are not of a capital, private or domestic nature.

The Commissioner does not accept that contributions by tobacco firms to an industry fund to be used to finance a campaign designed specifically against the Victorian Government proposals, would be deductible under those general provisions.

Such contributions would relate to the preservation of the status quo rather than to the promotion of a company's products. The Courts have held that expenditure incurred in preserving the capital structure of a business is of a capital nature and thus not deductible.
